A federal judge acknowledged the panic of oxygen deprivation but upheld the procedure. Alabama and Florida permit non-unanimous jury death sentences, a factor in Boyd’s 10–2 verdict.

articles.title: Trump in Asia: five key questions as US president prepares for diplomatic tour
articles.trailText: Donald Trump will travel to Malaysia, Japan and South Korea for the Apec and Asean summits. Will he meet Xi Jinping, and what tariff deals might be secured?
articles.summary: Trump begins his tour at the ASEAN summit in Malaysia, eyeing mediation in the Thailand–Cambodia border clash, before meeting Japan’s new PM Sanae Takaichi. In South Korea’s Apec forum he’s set to meet Xi Jinping to discuss rolling back 100% tariffs, Chinese soya imports, fentanyl controls, rare-earth exports and Taiwan, as extra duties loom. He’ll push for reciprocal tariff relief with Vietnam and Thailand, seek a $350bn South Korean investment deal after an ICE raid, but a fresh Kim summit seems unlikely.

articles.title: Trump backs down on sending federal troops to San Francisco for immigration crackdown
articles.trailText: Protesters flood streets in show of resistance, as president calls off deployment after speaking with city’s mayor and Silicon Valley leaders
articles.summary: President Trump canceled plans to send 100+ CBP and other federal agents to the Alameda Coast Guard base for an immigration enforcement "surge" in San Francisco after a call with Mayor Daniel Lurie and Silicon Valley CEOs. The deployment had ignited mass protests, condemnation from Gov. Gavin Newsom and clashes near the base with flash-bang grenades. Lurie and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem confirmed the call-off, but it's unclear if other Bay Area cities like Oakland remain targeted. Local leaders say they will continue to mobilize legal aid, rapid-response networks and demonstrations amid ongoing uncertainty over federal actions.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Trump scraps plan to send federal troops to San Francisco Bay Area
articles.trailText: President says San Francisco mayor and Silicon Valley leaders asked him to give the city ‘a chance’ – key US politics stories from Thursday 23 October at a glance
articles.summary: Donald Trump scrapped plans to deploy over 100 federal agents from Customs and Border Protection to the San Francisco Bay Area’s Alameda Coast Guard base for immigration enforcement after discussions with SF Mayor Daniel Lurie and Silicon Valley CEOs Marc Benioff and Jensen Huang. Other developments: major tech and defense firms are funding Trump’s $300m White House ballroom; a new book details infighting over ‘unqualified’ cabinet picks; House Democrats accuse him of a $230m taxpayer scheme; Trump pardons Binance’s founder; voters blame tariffs for rising costs; Colombia denounces US strikes; the Senate stalls pay for federal workers; and a lawsuit accuses Melania Trump’s meme coin architects of fraud as NBA stars face gambling probes.

articles.title: White House approves increased oil and gas drilling in Alaska’s national wildlife refuge
articles.trailText: National Petroleum Reserve lease sales and permitting for road through Izembek wildlife refuge were also approved
articles.summary: Trump administration reopens 1.56 m acres of ANWR coastal plain for oil and gas drilling, reverses Biden’s 2024 protections, and schedules National Petroleum Reserve-Alaska lease sale—the first since 2019. Permits reissued for the 211-mile Ambler Road through Izembek refuge threaten 200 k migratory birds and subsistence use by 37 tribes and 39 villages. Proponents cite access to a $7 bn copper deposit and other minerals; Interior Sec. Doug Burgum hails energy independence and jobs. Conservationists from Alaska Wilderness League, Earthjustice and Sierra Club warn of irreversible ecological and cultural damage.

articles.title: Trump says tech chiefs convinced him to call off troop ‘surge’ to San Francisco
articles.trailText: President specifically lauds Nvidia and Salesforce CEOs and says they told him ‘the future of San Francisco is great’
articles.summary: President Trump said he will call off a planned federal troop “surge” in San Francisco after pressure from Silicon Valley executives, notably Nvidia’s Jensen Huang and Salesforce’s Marc Benioff, who assured him “the future of San Francisco is great.” Trump had announced sending more than 100 federal agents for immigration and crime enforcement after Benioff’s initial endorsement sparked backlash and retraction. Critics warn this episode underscores the outsized influence of unaccountable tech CEOs over national policy, sidelining public input.

articles.title: US court rejects Trump officials’ effort to delay rulings on veterans benefits
articles.trailText: Unanimous ruling calls administration’s push to halt reviews of veterans’ disability appeals an “extreme request”
articles.summary: A Veterans Claims Court panel unanimously rejected VA Secretary Doug Collins’ bid to pause decisions on nearly all disability appeals during the government shutdown. In a 9-0 ruling led by Trump appointee Chief Judge Michael Allen, judges deemed the request “extreme” and unjustified. Veterans groups warned the move would indefinitely delay claims—some pending for decades over Agent Orange and burn-pit exposure. The court, which handles about 15,000 cases annually with a 222-day median resolution, will proceed with its reviews.

articles.title: Trump plans land strikes against alleged drug traffickers from Venezuela
articles.trailText: President says he ‘may go to the Congress and tell them … but I can’t imagine they’d have any problem with it’
articles.summary: Donald Trump said his administration may soon launch land-based strikes against alleged Venezuelan drug traffickers. Trump said “The land is going to be next” and is confident Congress would not object, potentially seeking formal approval after nine maritime attacks that killed at least 37 people. He and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth classify cartels as terrorists. Trump denied deploying B-1 bombers near Venezuela amid speculation anti-narcotics missions mask efforts to oust President Nicolás Maduro. Critics, including Democrat Sen. Mark Kelly, warn that bombing and talk of regime change risk American lives and mirror past failed interventions.

articles.title: US Senate fails to pass bill to pay federal essential workers and troops through shutdown
articles.trailText: ‘Shutdown fairness act’, introduced by Ron Johnson, Republican senator from Wisconsin, failed in a 54-45 vote
articles.summary: On day 23 of the US government shutdown, the Senate failed 54-45 to advance Sen. Ron Johnson’s “Shutdown Fairness Act,” which would guarantee pay for essential federal workers and troops during funding gaps. Democrats led by Schumer opposed it as a tool for Trump, though three Democrats—Fetterman, Ossoff and Warnock—voted yes. The shutdown has furloughed 700,000 workers and forced hundreds of thousands to work unpaid. Trump authorized the Defense Department to use R&D funds for troop pay. Democratic counter-bills from Peters and Van Hollen never reached a vote.

articles.title: Eric Adams to endorse Andrew Cuomo in New York City mayoral race
articles.trailText: Adams revealed decision in a New York Times interview a month after calling Cuomo a ‘snake and a liar’
articles.summary: NYC Mayor Eric Adams will endorse former Governor Andrew Cuomo in the upcoming mayoral race, reversing his previous criticism that labelled Cuomo a “snake and a liar.” Adams, who ended his own campaign after lagging in polls and saw corruption charges dropped, told the New York Times he’ll campaign alongside Cuomo in Black and Brown neighborhoods to address gentrification-driven rent hikes. His move counters democratic socialist Zohran Mamdani’s rise, was confirmed courtside at a Knicks opener, and has been rejected by both Mamdani and GOP candidate Curtis Sliwa.

articles.title: Illinois warns immigration officers tampering with license plates is illegal
articles.trailText: Hotline introduced to report on agents’ vehicles after one said plates were changed every day in video
articles.summary: Illinois officials launched a “Plate Watch” hotline after a viral video showed an ICE officer claiming to change Illinois plates daily. Secretary of State Alexi Giannoulias warned that swapping or altering license plates on Illinois-registered vehicles violates state law, carrying fines, jail time and plate suspension or revocation. The measure underscores no one is above the law. Illinois requires front and rear plates; out-of-state vehicles must display proper state licensing. The move follows calls for body cameras on ICE in Chicago and broader legislation and state bans to ensure agents visibly identify themselves.

articles.title: Top House Democrats accuse Trump of illegal scheme to pilfer $230m in taxpayer money
articles.trailText: Lawmakers say Trump as president would decide whether Trump as claimant be paid for investigations into Trump as defendant
articles.summary: Top House Democrats Jamie Raskin and Robert Garcia say President Trump is pursuing an illegal, secretive $230 million payout from taxpayers via a confidential DoJ administrative restitution process tied to investigations into him. In a Thursday letter they demand he abandon what they call an unconstitutional plan that could evade disclosure until year-end. Democracy Forward has filed a records request for related DoJ documents. Trump has insisted he alone decides if the government “owes him a lot” for probes like the Mar-a-Lago search. A DOJ spokesperson says all officials follow career ethics guidance.

articles.title: Most voters in swing House districts fault Trump trade moves for high prices
articles.trailText: New survey by Democrats also finds many are unhappy with signature Republican tax bill and healthcare cuts
articles.summary: An Oct. 2–6 DCCC poll of 1,000 likely voters in 61 swing House districts finds 61% blame Trump’s tariffs—averaging 58% on Chinese imports—for driving up consumer prices, and 52% oppose the GOP’s One Big Beautiful Bill Act (implementing his tax package, funding immigration enforcement and shrinking Medicaid). Though Trump won these seats by 4 points in 2024, Democrats lead the generic midterm ballot 47%–43%. After the recent shutdown, 43% fault Trump and Republicans. Rising costs and healthcare cuts boost voter discontent ahead of 2026.

articles.title: DC man who played Darth Vader theme at national guard troops sues over arrest
articles.trailText: Sam O’Hara was arrested after a guard member allegedly complained about his blasting Star Wars song at troops
articles.summary: Sam O’Hara, a DC resident, has filed a federal lawsuit alleging First and Fourth Amendment violations after being handcuffed for playing Star Wars’ ‘Imperial March’ while trailing Ohio National Guard troops in an anti-Trump deployment protest. Represented by the ACLU, O’Hara names four officers, one guard member and the District of Columbia, accusing them of false arrest, false imprisonment and battery under DC law. He seeks a ruling that his peaceful, TikTok-documented protest was protected speech and compensatory damages. His suit echoes recent humor-driven protests, from inflatable frog marches to a giraffe-suited comedian suing ICE.

articles.title: Top US prosecutor’s use of text message auto-delete could be illegal, watchdog groups warn
articles.trailText: Lindsey Halligan, who brought cases against James Comey and Letitia James, allegedly violated records-retention laws
articles.summary: Interim US Attorney Lindsey Halligan used Signal with an eight-hour auto-delete setting when discussing her criminal case against New York AG Letitia James with Lawfare reporter Anna Bower—actions watchdogs say may breach the Federal Records Act and DOJ retention policies. American Oversight has filed a FOIA request for her messages, and CREW urged a DOJ Inspector General probe. Federal law requires preserving official communications. Halligan, a Trump appointee who also indicted former FBI Director James Comey, faces allegations of record-destruction amid broader politicization concerns at the DOJ.

articles.title: Melania Trump’s meme coin architects accused of pump-and-dump fraud in lawsuit
articles.trailText: First lady not named in suit in which investors allege Meteora platform created crypto they knew would plummet
articles.summary: Investors filed suit in Manhattan federal court accusing Meteora exchange executives of orchestrating a pump-and-dump of the $MELANIA meme coin launched Jan. 19 alongside $TRUMP. Plaintiffs allege insiders inflated $MELANIA’s price from cents to $13.73 before dumping shares, crashing it back to about $0.10. $TRUMP peaked at $45.47 and now trades near $5.79. Melania Trump isn’t named as culpable; her brand was allegedly used as window dressing. These claims augment ongoing crypto lawsuits as the Trump family reportedly earned over $1bn in crypto profits last year.

articles.title: Marine heatwave over Pacific Ocean could lead to flooding in north-west
articles.trailText: Severe ‘blob’ or marine heatwave can lead to increased inundation and wintery weather in eastern North America
articles.summary: Scientists warn a ‘blob’ marine heatwave in the north-west/central Pacific—August temperatures 2.5 °C above preindustrial—could heighten flood risk in the US Pacific north-west, fuel storms and influence eastern North American winter weather, while driving harmful algal blooms and marine species migrations. Coined by UW climatologist Nick Bond, such ocean heat anomalies have grown more frequent and severe over the past decade (2014–16 event reached +3 °C, halting shellfish fisheries). Though linked in media to a snowy Chicago, experts say its inland impact is secondary amid other climate drivers and limited historical data.

articles.title: New book details infighting behind Trump’s ‘obviously unqualified’ cabinet picks
articles.trailText: Retribution, by Jonathan Karl, describes backroom squabbling over Kristi Noem and Sean Duffy appointments
articles.summary: Jonathan Karl’s Retribution reveals Trump’s chaotic cabinet selections, spotlighting his pick of South Dakota Gov. Kristi Noem as homeland security secretary at campaign manager Corey Lewandowski’s request despite no vetting or relevant experience—spark­ing alarm from allies like Steve Bannon and later criticism over spending, immigration overreach and so-called “authoritarian cosplay.” The book also details ex-Rep. Sean Duffy’s appointment as transportation secretary (and acting NASA admin) despite no policy background, as Trump rebuffed rivals, spurned Emil Michael and overlooked a decade-old slight unearthed by Howard Lutnick’s sabotage attempt.

articles.title: Four members of Illinois politician’s family killed in helicopter crash
articles.trailText: Darren Bailey’s son, daughter-in-law and two grandchildren all killed in accident in Montana
articles.summary: Darren Bailey, a former Illinois state senator and 2026 gubernatorial candidate, is grieving the deaths of his son, Zachary, daughter-in-law Kelsey and grandchildren Vada Rose (12) and Samuel (7), who died in a helicopter crash in Montana. Their 10-year-old son Finn survived. A campaign statement on X Thursday said Darren and Cindy are heartbroken, leaning on faith and family. Authorities have yet to release crash location, helicopter type or cause. Bailey, who lost to Democrat JB Pritzker in 2022, is mounting a second bid on a conservative platform.

articles.title: Donors for Trump’s $300m White House ballroom include Google, Apple and Palantir
articles.trailText: Work under way to demolish entire East Wing as president upped cost of new structure from $200m to $300m
articles.summary: Tech giants Apple, Amazon, Meta, Microsoft and Google; defense contractors Booz Allen Hamilton, Lockheed Martin and Palantir; and donors Miriam Adelson, Stephen Schwarzman, Harold Hamm, the Winklevoss twins and Howard Lutnick are financing former President Trump’s 90,000 sq ft White House ballroom, cost now $300 million vs $200 million initially. East Wing demolition began without public notice or review, bypassing the shutdown National Capital Planning Commission. Trump insists it’s “100%” donor-funded, hosting select contributors at a White House dinner. House Democrats and preservation groups decry the secretive process and legal review lapses; the administration promises post-demolition plan filings and cites digital archival efforts by the Historical Association.

articles.title: Revealed: police across US spread false rumors about Venezuelan gang threats
articles.trailText: Claim that Tren de Aragua planned to attack officers was widely shared – only for FBI to later acknowledge it was mistaken, internal files show
articles.summary: An unverified rumor that Venezuela’s Tren de Aragua gang ordered members to attack US police spread rapidly after a July 2024 Albuquerque police bulletin. Shared by CBP, DHS, the Texas governor, GOP lawmakers and conservative media, it bolstered hard-line immigration and border security stances. Internal FBI files months later labeled the threat inaccurate and primarily defensive. Experts say TdA has no clear US hierarchy. The episode spurred deportations, lethal strikes on suspect vessels and illustrates how thinly sourced intelligence can drive policy and fear.

articles.title: First Thing: US imposes sanctions on Russian oil over Putin’s ‘refusal’ to end war in Ukraine
articles.trailText: The Trump administration hardens its stance against the Kremlin. Plus, the final New York City mayoral debate gets heated
articles.summary: The US imposed sanctions on Rosneft and Lukoil—Russia’s two largest oil firms—to penalize Putin’s refusal to end the Ukraine war. As the first Russian energy sanctions under Trump since January, they target oil tax revenues that supply about a quarter of Moscow’s budget, aiming to strangle financing for the Kremlin’s war machine and force an immediate ceasefire. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said “now is the time to stop the killing.” Nonetheless, analysts at the Council on Foreign Relations warn the Kremlin has been adept at evading such restrictions.

articles.title: Trump’s ballroom blitz sparks chorus of disgust: ‘The perfect symbol’
articles.trailText: Obama once joked about what a gaudy Trump White House would look like – the president seems bent on proving him right
articles.summary: Donald Trump has demolished the White House’s East Wing façade to build a $250 million, 90,000 sq ft gilded ballroom—echoing Mar-a-Lago decor and funded by undisclosed private donations—to host up to 999 guests. Critics from White House alumni and historians denounce the wrecking crew’s rubble as “the perfect symbol” of his second term’s norm-busting excess, echoing Obama’s 2011 satire of a casino-style presidency. Trump proceeded without National Capital Planning Commission approval, while the National Trust warns the ballroom will overwhelm the 55,000 sq ft residence.

articles.title: US military kills five people in strikes on alleged drug-trafficking boats in Pacific
articles.trailText: Latest strikes were off coast of Colombia, while seven previous attacks in Caribbean killed at least 32
articles.summary: On 22 Oct, US forces struck and destroyed two suspected cocaine-smuggling boats off Colombia’s Pacific coast, killing five, after seven Caribbean strikes killed at least 32. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth compared cartels to al-Qaida, warning of “no refuge or forgiveness.” Colombia’s president Gustavo Petro denounced the Pacific attack as murder and breach of international law. The CIA supplied most targeting intelligence under a covert Trump authorization. The White House cites controversial FTO designations and article-2 self-defense powers. Strikes overseen by Stephen Miller’s homeland security council unit bypassed NSC protocols, drawing criticism from rights groups.

articles.title: Shouting and ready to ‘bump chests’ with Trump – but nobody moved the needle in the final New York mayoral debate
articles.trailText: Andrew Cuomo belittled Zohran Mamdani’s lack of experience. The Democrat countered that his much older opponents ‘speak only in the past because that is all they know’
articles.summary: In the razor-sharp final New York mayoral debate, Democratic frontrunner Zohran Mamdani, independent Andrew Cuomo and Republican Curtis Sliwa traded barbs on experience, education reform, transit and Rikers Island closure. Cuomo derided Mamdani’s youth while Mamdani invoked accuser Charlotte Bennett to spotlight Cuomo’s harassment scandal. Sliwa punctuated proceedings with sharp zingers. Despite fierce generational and ideological clashes over Israel policy, ICE enforcement and standing up to Trump, no candidate delivered a breakthrough, leaving Mamdani’s double-digit lead intact ahead of early voting.

articles.title: Cuomo condemned over racist AI ad depicting ‘criminals for Zohran Mamdani’
articles.trailText: Official X accounts posts and then deletes AI-generated attack ad that prompts widespread denunciation
articles.summary: During the second NYC mayoral debate, Andrew Cuomo’s official @andrewcuomo account posted and swiftly deleted an AI-generated attack ad labeling supporters of rival Zohran Mamdani as criminals. The two-minute video—reshared by journalist Prem Thakker—depicted an AI caricature of Mamdani plus stereotyped criminals: a shoplifting Black man in keffiyeh, a sex trafficker, a drug dealer, all shown pledging support. Critics including Shannon Watts, Laila Al-Arian and Benjamín Schultz-Figueroa denounced its racist tropes. It follows Cuomo’s earlier AI ads portraying himself in city roles and satirizing Bill de Blasio. Mamdani called Cuomo’s AI approach “fake Cuomo.”

articles.title: Personal attacks rather than policy: key takeaways from New York’s final mayoral debate
articles.trailText: Candidates jockeyed for advantage during debate, but were unlikely to change voters’ minds before election day
articles.summary: In the final NYC mayoral debate, Democratic frontrunner Zohran Mamdani clashed with independent Andrew Cuomo and Republican Curtis Sliwa, trading personal attacks over housing delays, harassment allegations and policy clarity. ICE raids turned debate into Trump’s influence: Cuomo vowed curb low-level enforcement; Mamdani called him ‘Trump’s puppet’; Sliwa would negotiate with Trump. Sliwa quipped at both rivals, while Jewish safety became a flashpoint as Cuomo and Sliwa accused Mamdani of enabling antisemitism. Mamdani, accused of dodging education and zoning questions, defended his affordability agenda. With days to election, all three stuck to entrenched narratives.

articles.title: Mamdani, Cuomo and Sliwa fling zingers in New York mayoral debate
articles.trailText: Final debate was marked by heated exchanges between the frontrunners, while Sliwa quipped at Cuomo’s expense
articles.summary: On October 22 in the final televised debate before Election Day, Democrat Zohran Mamdani, independent Andrew Cuomo and Republican Curtis Sliwa sparred over immigration enforcement, homelessness, housing policy, rent freezes and police power. Mamdani accused rivals of fearmongering and proposed doubling shelter check-ins, rent freezes and a $30 minimum wage; Cuomo touted past infrastructure, defended rent hikes, advocated targeted ICE crackdowns and critiqued Mamdani’s inexperience; Sliwa quipped “negotiate with Trump,” attacked both for failings and opposed zoning reforms. Sharp zingers flew over anti-Semitism, harassment allegations and Rikers’ closure. Early voting runs October 25–November 2; election is November 4.

articles.title: New York unveils portal for public to share ICE footage after four US citizens arrested
articles.trailText: Attorney general Letitia James urges residents to share video and photos amid outcry over Chinatown raid
articles.summary: New York AG Letitia James launched a “Federal Action Reporting Portal” inviting residents to submit photos, videos and locations of ICE actions after a forceful raid in Manhattan’s Chinatown left four US citizens detained nearly 24 hours. That raid, involving over 50 masked agents, armored vehicles and mass detentions, sparked nightly protests and political backlash from Governor Hochul, mayoral candidates and Congressman Dan Goldman. The portal’s waiver lets James’s office use submissions publicly to investigate potential legal violations amid escalating ICE operations.

articles.title: Pregnant women report medical neglect in ICE detention, rights groups say
articles.trailText: Women report miscarriages, delayed care, being shackled and being held in solitary confinement, letter says
articles.summary: A coalition of civil rights groups including the ACLU, National Immigration Project and RFK Human Rights reported that more than a dozen pregnant women in ICE detention experienced medical neglect: miscarriages, bleeding, shackling during transport, solitary confinement, delayed or inadequate prenatal care, denial of vitamins, poor food, lack of translation, non-consensual procedures and infections at facilities in Louisiana and Georgia. One detainee endured excruciating invasive tests without explanation, miscarried, then remained detained amid worsening symptoms. Advocates call for release, timely medical care and closure of violative centers. DHS labels allegations unverified, citing oversight protocols.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Oil prices jump after president puts sanctions on Russia in major policy shift
articles.trailText: Trump, who has to date not put sanctions on Russia over the war and instead relied on trade measures, says Rosneft and Lukoil will be targeted. Key US politics stories from Wednesday 22 October
articles.summary: President Trump imposed Ukraine-related sanctions on Rosneft and Lukoil—the first war-linked measures of his second term—pushing oil prices up over $2 a barrel and signaling frustration with Putin after a shelved Budapest summit. Previously he’d relied on trade tools, including 25% tariffs on Indian imports. Other updates: the White House East Wing faces imminent demolition despite no filed ballroom plans; Trump asserts sole authority over payouts from past probes; a US naval strike in the Pacific killed two; UVA bowed to DOJ pressure on admissions and hiring equity; Maine Senate candidate covered a Nazi-linked tattoo; Sen. Jeff Merkley spoke for 23 hours decrying Trump’s alleged authoritarianism; Democrats urged Israel to free a detained Palestinian-American teen; and Health Sec. RFK Jr. championed cutting ultra-processed foods even as some policies undercut that goal.

articles.title: Trump poised to send scores of federal agents to San Francisco
articles.trailText: Newsom calls move ‘right out of the dictator’s handbook’ as agents prepare for key immigration enforcement operation
articles.summary: The Trump administration is set to deploy over 100 federal agents to the San Francisco Bay Area, using the Alameda Coast Guard base as a staging ground for a major immigration enforcement operation. Governor Gavin Newsom, SF Mayor Daniel Lurie and Assemblymember Mia Bonta condemn the move as authoritarian, vowing legal challenges under the Insurrection Act and new city protections for immigrant communities. Local groups and the Lawyers’ Committee for Civil Rights are organizing rallies, vigils and legal readiness in predominantly Latino neighborhoods, advising residents on their rights amid heightened federal enforcement.

articles.title: White House East Wing will be torn down ‘within days’ even as no plans filed for Trump’s new ballroom
articles.trailText: Demolition has drawn fierce backlash, with National Trust for Historic Preservation saying plans are ‘legally required’
articles.summary: Officials say the White House’s East Wing will be razed in days despite no plans filed with the National Capital Planning Commission for Donald Trump’s 90,000 sq ft, privately funded ($200M) ballroom. Trump defended removing the “small” wing to build a glass-bridge-connected “finest ballroom ever,” while press secretary Leavitt decries “fake outrage.” The National Trust for Historic Preservation warns the demolition violated legally required public review, citing risks to the White House’s classical massing and urging a pause.

articles.title: US imposes sanctions on Russian oil over Putin’s ‘refusal’ to end war in Ukraine
articles.trailText: Trump administration hardens stance against the Kremlin day after cancelling a planned summit with Russian leader
articles.summary: The Trump administration has imposed its first Russia sanctions since January on oil giants Rosneft and Lukoil, aiming to sever Kremlin revenue streams financing Putin’s war in Ukraine after his refusal to negotiate a ceasefire. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent warned of further steps and called on allies to join, following UK penalties on both firms and EU sanctions only on Rosneft due to member exemptions. Trump also cancelled a planned Putin summit and denied approving Ukraine’s use of Storm Shadow missiles. Brussels praised the move ahead of its 19th sanctions package targeting Russian energy, finance and shipping firms.

articles.title: University of Virginia agrees to Trump administration demands over admissions and hiring
articles.trailText: School joins University of Pennsylvania, Columbia and Brown in bowing to White House to restore funding
articles.summary: Facing threats of funding cuts and litigation, the University of Virginia became the first public institution to settle with the Trump Justice Department in October 2025. Under the deal—prompted by President Jim Ryan’s June resignation—UVA commits to ending unlawful racial discrimination in admissions, hiring and programming and to provide quarterly compliance data through 2028. In exchange, the DOJ halts its investigation. UVA follows Penn, Columbia and Brown in exchanging diversity policy changes for restored federal funding, sparking concerns over administrative coercion in higher education. Senator Mark Warner warned that failure to comply risked mass layoffs, revoked research grants, and loss of student visas or financial aid.

articles.title: Democratic senator’s anti-Trump floor speech ends after nearly 23 hours
articles.trailText: Jeff Merkley of Oregon gives address to make case that president is ‘violating the law’ through authoritarianism
articles.summary: Senator Jeff Merkley delivered a nearly 23-hour Senate speech accusing President Trump of authoritarianism—deploying federal troops to cities like Portland and Chicago, prosecuting political enemies (e.g., Letitia James), and shredding constitutional norms. Joined by Chuck Schumer, Cory Booker and Richard Blumenthal, Merkley warned of "the greatest threat to our republic since the Civil War," citing federal appeals court approval of military deployments and government shutdown deadlock. He held placards reading "Authoritarianism is here now!" and praised recent anti-Trump "No Kings" protests. His marathon address echoed Booker’s 25-hour filibuster, aiming to ring alarm bells about democracy’s erosion.

articles.title: Pentagon names new press corps from far-right outlets after reporter walkout
articles.trailText: Spokesperson calls journalists who refused to agree to new rules ‘self-righteous media who chose to self-deport’
articles.summary: After Pentagon reporters, including mainstream and conservative outlets, refused to sign new rules barring unauthorized information and restricting access, the Defense Department has named a “next-generation” press corps of 60 journalists from far-right outlets such as Lindell TV, Gateway Pundit, the Post Millennial, Human Events, National Pulse, Turning Point USA’s Frontlines, Tim Pool’s Timcast and the Substack-based Washington Reporter. Spokesperson Sean Parnell praised them as more effective than the “self-righteous” departed media, despite many promoting conspiracy theories and facing defamation settlements, marking a sharp shift in Pentagon media relations.

articles.title: LA TikTok creator streaming ICE raids charged with assault after being shot
articles.trailText: Carlitos Ricardo Parias remained hospitalized after he was shot in the elbow by federal agents during arrest
articles.summary: Los Angeles TikTok creator Carlitos Ricardo Parias, known as Richard LA for livestreaming ICE raids, was shot in the elbow and arrested by federal agents on Oct. 22 after allegedly attempting to ram their vehicles to evade an administrative arrest warrant. A ricochet also wounded a deputy US marshal. Charged with assaulting a federal officer, the 44-year-old remains hospitalized, delaying his court appearance, and faces up to eight years in prison. Parias, who has a large following and was honored by a city council member for spotlighting South Central LA, has drawn praise from immigrant rights advocates criticizing escalating ICE tactics.

articles.title: Trump takes a wrecking ball to the White House in on-the-nose metaphor
articles.trailText: The start of construction on the president’s $250m ballroom marks a regression to his property wheeler-dealer days
articles.summary: President Trump began demolishing part of the East Wing to build a $250 million private ballroom, funded by himself and unnamed donors, drawing criticism for the literal “wrecking ball” symbolism amid norm erosion. Historians likened it to defacing a masterpiece. The White House cited past expansions. Observers note Trump’s second-term pivot from a stalling economy to foreign policy and real estate nostalgia, echoing Mar-a-Lago opulence. He also unveiled plans for a gold-topped triumphal arch dubbed 'Arc de Trump.'

articles.title: Top Democrat on House oversight panel demands Pam Bondi release Epstein files
articles.trailText: Robert Garcia cited revelations from Virginia Giuffre’s posthumous memoir in letter to the attorney general
articles.summary: House oversight panel’s Democratic ranking member Robert Garcia has demanded Florida Attorney General Pam Bondi release all records on Jeffrey Epstein’s prosecution, citing new allegations in Virginia Giuffre’s posthumous memoir, Nobody’s Girl, which details grooming by Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell and implicates prominent figures. Garcia says these revelations contradict Justice Department claims that further inquiry wasn’t warranted and warns Bondi’s refusal to comply with an August subpoena raises questions about her motives. The committee, investigating Epstein’s 2019 death, has released thousands of pages of documents and may force a vote on legislation to unlock more files once the shutdown ends.

articles.title: US demands EU reverse new climate rules to allow surge in gas imports
articles.trailText: US and Qatar say new rules will hinder imports of LNG, posing ‘existential threat’ to European economies
articles.summary: The US and Qatar, two of the world’s top LNG exporters, sent a joint letter urging the EU to repeal or weaken its new corporate sustainability due diligence directive, warning it poses an "existential threat" by blocking imports unless human rights safeguards and emissions cuts are met. Debated by EU legislators next week, the directive mandates exporters to prove climate and rights compliance or face fines. Concurrently, the Trump administration approved Venture Global’s CP2 LNG terminal in Louisiana - exporting 3.96bn cubic feet/day and emitting 190m tons CO2/year - while critics cite higher US energy costs, local pollution in Cameron Parish, and worsened climate impacts.

articles.title: US man accused of keeping four adults in basement also faces murder charges
articles.trailText: South Carolina man is now charged with murder of 49-year-old woman, as well as criminal sexual conduct
articles.summary: Authorities in Lancaster, South Carolina, have charged 35-year-old Donnie Ray Birchfield Jr. with the July murder of 49-year-old Shirley Arnsdorff and first-degree criminal sexual conduct after uncovering evidence that he had imprisoned her, her husband and two other women in his basement for years. Police allege Birchfield denied the captives food and medical care, subjected them to abuse and siphoned their funds via bank cards. Initially arrested on August 1 for false imprisonment, exploitation and financial identity fraud, Birchfield, who denies wrongdoing, remains held without bond. Lancaster officials call the case heartbreaking and seek additional tips to support the ongoing investigation.

articles.title: Protests erupt in New York City after ICE raids Chinatown over ‘counterfeit goods’
articles.trailText: Demonstrators were seen near a federal building after an unknown number of detainees were taken by agents
articles.summary: Early Tuesday, ICE joined by FBI, DEA, ATF, IRS-CI and CBP executed an intelligence-driven raid on Canal Street in Manhattan’s Chinatown, targeting vendors selling counterfeit handbags, accessories and jewelry. Over 50 masked, armed agents—including an armored vehicle—were filmed zip-tying and detaining at least seven individuals and shoving onlookers. Hours later, hundreds protested outside 26 Federal Plaza, chanting “ICE out of New York” and denouncing federal violence. Local officials from Mayor Adams to Councilmember Marte and advocacy leaders called the operation ‘‘authoritarian and reckless,’’ highlighting arrests of vendors and bystanders and demanding an end to aggressive ICE tactics.

articles.title: Democrats call on Rubio to help secure release of Palestinian-American teen held in Israeli prison
articles.trailText: Group of 27 Congress members wrote to Marco Rubio to call for ‘swift release’ of 16-year-old Mohammed Ibrahim
articles.summary: Twenty-seven Democratic lawmakers, led by Senators Chris Van Hollen and Jeff Merkley and Reps. Kathy Castor and Maxwell Frost, urged Sec. of State Marco Rubio and the US ambassador to Israel to secure the swift release of 16-year-old Palestinian-American Mohammed Ibrahim, held in Israeli military detention since February. Arrested at 15 in a blindfolded, handcuffed predawn raid on his family’s West Bank home, Ibrahim has suffered weight loss, scabies and limited consular access. Signatories including Sanders, Warren, Schiff and Warnock demand a progress report by Nov. 3. The appeal coincides with Rubio’s Israel visit and amid concerns following the Gaza ceasefire transition talks.

articles.title: Boycotts, strikes and more protests: organizers on what’s next for No Kings
articles.trailText: Leaders of groups behind mass protests against Trump administration map out their vision
articles.summary: The No Kings alliance is scaling its mass-protest energy into a nationwide Rapid Response Network that will mobilize weekly actions—boycotts, campus campaigns, street protests and electoral organizing—tailored to local communities’ needs, from school boards to gerrymandering fights. After 7 million rallied, leaders celebrated geographic breadth into Trump country and signaled more disruptive tactics, including a possible general strike. Major groups (Indivisible, ACLU, SEIU, Black Voters Matter, Public Citizen) pledge coordinated boycotts, legal challenges, mutual aid and voter engagement to sustain defiance against an increasingly authoritarian administration.

articles.title: New York officials condemn Manhattan ICE raid: ‘This creates fear and chaos’
articles.trailText: Hochul, Schumer and the three mayoral candidates express outrage over federal operation in Chinatown
articles.summary: Dozens of masked ICE agents raided Manhattan’s Chinatown Tuesday, detaining street vendors near Canal Street in an operation DHS said targeted counterfeit goods traffickers. The NYPD pledged no involvement; Mayor Adams reiterated the city’s noncooperation on civil deportations. Gov. Hochul, Senator Schumer, Public Advocate Williams and Comptroller Lander decried the raid as reckless, fear-mongering and a violation of due process. Mayoral candidates Mamdani, Cuomo and Sliwa likewise faulted the Trump administration’s “authoritarian theatrics,” urging focus on serious criminals, not immigrant workers.

articles.title: Trump says he has final say on paying himself $230m for past investigations
articles.trailText: President says government owes him ‘a lot of money’ for federal investigations during and after first term
articles.summary: President Trump insisted any decision to award him roughly $230 million in damages for past DOJ probes—including his August 2024 claim of malicious prosecution over the FBI Mar-a-Lago search and a challenge to the 2016 Russia interference investigation—'would have to go across my desk.' He conceded the circularity of suing himself under the Federal Tort Claims Act, which bars discretionary acts, and floated donating proceeds or funding a White House ballroom. Career DOJ civil-division staff, now overseen by Trump loyalists Todd Blanche and Stanley Woodward, would vet the unprecedented claims. A DOJ spokesman emphasized adherence to career ethics guidance.

articles.title: California to set aside $80m and deploy national guard to assist food banks amid shutdown
articles.trailText: Gavin Newsom criticized Trump for ‘endangering people’s lives’ as shutdown sets stage for delayed food benefits
articles.summary: California governor Gavin Newsom announced $80m in state funds and National Guard deployment to bolster food banks as the ongoing federal shutdown—one of the longest on record—threatens to delay SNAP benefits. His move targets 5.5m Californians (63% children/elderly) facing higher grocery prices before Thanksgiving. Newsom blamed President Trump and congressional Republicans for endangering lives after cuts to SNAP for 41.7m Americans under Trump’s summer 'One Big Beautiful Bill Act.' GOP leaders, by contrast, accuse Democrats of causing the lapse.

articles.title: Wild bear pays surprise visit to bear enclosure at California zoo: ‘He was very polite’
articles.trailText: Sequoia park zoo said staff were doing an inspection when they saw a wild black bear looking in at three captive bears
articles.summary: At Sequoia Park Zoo in Eureka, California, staff spotted a wild American black bear leaning on a gate and peering at three captive black bears during a routine inspection. The uninvited guest showed no aggression, interacted through fencing, and briefly explored enrichment items near the night house. Zoo personnel safely lured the bear—likely from the adjacent 60-acre Sequoia Park woodland—back into the forest via a service gate. Officials praised the visitor’s “polite” behavior: remaining on the boardwalk path, keeping all feet on the ground and not attempting to scale any railings.

articles.title: US ‘Night Stalkers’ seen in Caribbean as fears of regime change rise in Venezuela
articles.trailText: Elite helicopter unit’s part in military deployment comes as Donald Trump ramps up pressure on Nicolás Maduro
articles.summary: The US Army’s elite Night Stalkers (160th SOAR), famed for covert night missions like the raid on Osama bin Laden, are now training 90 miles off Venezuela’s coast with Little Birds, Black Hawks, B-52s and F-35s. Deployed under Trump’s escalated Caribbean military pressure—plus covert CIA ops and recent US missile strikes—this signals a high-probability push to oust Nicolás Maduro. Analysts warn of potential urban combat and a calibrated campaign to sway Venezuela’s armed forces.

articles.title: US firearms examiners declared ‘essential’ shutdown workers after gun-lobby pressure
articles.trailText: Americans able to buy deadly ‘gangster weapons’ again as lobbying forces key concession from Trump officials
articles.summary: Under the federal shutdown, ATF’s NFA examiners were furloughed, halting sales of silencers, short-barreled rifles and pre-1986 machine guns. After the National Shooting Sports Foundation and 30 Republican lawmakers lobbied Attorney General Pam Bondi and acting ATF director Daniel Driscoll, examiners were reclassified as “essential” and returned to work, resuming these high-risk transfers. While handguns, shotguns, rifles and background checks continued uninterrupted, critics say prioritizing NFA firearm processing amid stalled drug approvals, small-business loans and nuclear oversight reveals misplaced priorities. The NSSF hailed it as a Second Amendment victory; gun-control groups decry the public safety risk.

articles.title: JD Vance expresses ‘great optimism’ Gaza truce will hold during Israel visit | First Thing
articles.trailText: Gaza’s media office says Israel killed at least 80 Palestinians since ceasefire deal took effect. Plus, Trump’s pick for whistleblower office drops out after racist texts
articles.summary: Senator JD Vance, on a visit to Israel Tuesday, hailed the Gaza ceasefire as “durable” and “going better than expected,” part of Trump administration efforts to solidify the truce after Israeli airstrikes killed 26 Palestinians. Gaza’s media office reports at least 80 violations and fatalities since the deal, while Qatar’s emir condemned continued breaches. Hamas and Israeli officials resumed Cairo talks over hostages and contested terms. Elsewhere, Trump nominee Paul Ingrassia withdrew over racist texts, and CIA intelligence drives US drug boat strikes in the Caribbean.

articles.title: Tip on GoFundMe leads to arrest of suspect in deadly 2017 Arizona stabbing
articles.trailText: Message sent to fundraising site led investigators to man accused of stabbing Evin Paulos about 30 times
articles.summary: In September, an anonymous tip to a GoFundMe page set up by the family of slain Evin Paulos led investigators to arrest Michael Anthony Arredondo in Mexico on Oct. 15. Arredondo is accused of fatally stabbing 25-year-old Paulos about 30 times in June 2017 after a falling-out. Mexican authorities, US Marshals and Phoenix police extradited him to Arizona, where he confessed to second-degree murder and was ordered held on $1.5 million bail. Paulos’s sister expressed relief that justice may finally be served.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Rare Republican pushback forces Trump nominee to lead whistleblower office to drop out
articles.trailText: Paul Ingrassia dropped out of consideration after racist text messages he sent surfaced this week. Key US politics stories from 21 October 2025 at a glance
articles.summary: Paul Ingrassia, Trump’s choice to head the federal whistleblower protection office, withdrew after racist texts in which he admitted a “Nazi streak” and attacked Martin Luther King Jr. surfaced, triggering rare GOP opposition led by Senate Majority Leader John Thune. Other headlines: planned Trump–Putin talks in Budapest are on hold amid Ukraine ceasefire diplomacy; VP J.D. Vance expresses optimism over a Gaza truce; Arizona sues House Speaker Mike Johnson for delaying a Democrat’s swearing-in; Johnson says he won’t block a vote to release Epstein files; North Carolina Republicans unveil a new congressional map; and a Trump-pardoned Jan. 6 defendant was arrested for threatening House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.

articles.title: Trump nominee to lead whistleblower office drops out after racist texts surface
articles.trailText: Report on Paul Ingrassia featured messages where he allegedly described himself as having a ‘Nazi streak’
articles.summary: Paul Ingrassia, Trump’s nominee to head the Office of Special Counsel, withdrew from his HSGAC confirmation hearing after Politico published text messages where he claimed a “Nazi streak” and disparaged MLK Jr Day. Facing opposition from Senate GOP leaders including John Thune and Ron Johnson and likely bipartisan rejection, Ingrassia cited insufficient Republican votes. His attorney contested the messages’ authenticity. Earlier controversies include a DHS workplace complaint. At 30 and admitted to the bar last year, he lacked the veteran legal credentials typical for overseeing whistleblower protections.

articles.title: Arizona sues Mike Johnson to force swearing-in of Democrat who could sway Epstein vote
articles.trailText: Adelita Grijalva was elected last month but Republican House speaker has so far blocked her from taking seat
articles.summary: Arizona attorney general Kris Mayes sued House Speaker Mike Johnson to compel the swearing-in of Adelita Grijalva, a Democrat who won a special election on September 23 in her late father’s district. Johnson has refused to seat her, citing the federal shutdown, leaving Grijalva without official resources. Democrats allege he’s blocking her pivotal 218th vote on releasing Jeffrey Epstein files. Mayes calls it taxation without representation and an unconstitutional disenfranchisement. Senate Democrats have pressed Johnson, who denies any Epstein connection and blames the shutdown. Mayes had demanded her oath within two days after an October 14 letter.

articles.title: Deputy US marshal and man shot during Ice operation in Los Angeles
articles.trailText: Investigation after federal officers shot at man during ‘targeted traffic stop’ and agent was hit by ricochet bullet
articles.summary: Investigators are probing a south Los Angeles ICE traffic stop in which 44-year-old Carlitos Ricardo Parias allegedly rammed agents’ vehicles and was shot in the elbow; a deputy US marshal sustained a ricochet wound to the hand. Both were hospitalized. Parias has been charged with assault on a federal officer, facing up to eight years in prison. DHS blamed “sanctuary” rhetoric for rising violence, citing unverified ICE attack data, while immigration activists decry increasingly aggressive federal tactics amid recent raid fatalities.

articles.title: North Carolina Republicans advance map to secure another seat in Congress
articles.trailText: State house set to pass map to turn 10-4 Republican split into 11-3 – and state law does not give governor a veto
articles.summary: North Carolina’s GOP-controlled state senate approved a new congressional district map to shift the current 10–4 Republican–Democrat split to 11–3, targeting Democrat Don Davis’s northeast seat. With no gubernatorial veto, the Republican-majority house will likely pass it imminently. Republicans cite electoral cycles; Democrats warn of partisan gerrymandering undermining bipartisanship and rural Black representation in the majority-Black First District. The redraft avoids racial lines to preempt litigation, but comes as the US Supreme Court weighs a Voting Rights Act challenge. It reflects a broader national trend following Rucho v. Common Cause, which left partisan gerrymandering largely unchecked.

articles.title: ‘I’m not a secret Nazi’: Maine Democratic Senate candidate addresses tattoo
articles.trailText: Graham Platner says he didn’t know historical associations of skull-and-crossbones tattoo he got on his chest in 2007
articles.summary: Graham Platner, Maine Democratic Senate hopeful, preemptively disclosed a 2007 chest skull-and-crossbones tattoo obtained with Marine teammates in Croatia, unaware it resembled the Nazi SS Totenkopf symbol. On Pod Save America, he insisted he never intended Nazi homage, plans removal, and shared a video dancing in underwear at his brother’s wedding with the tattoo visible. He highlighted his anti-racism stance and apology for past inflammatory Reddit posts, which included calling police “bastards” and stereotyping Black and rural white voters. Critics, including a former aide, question his professed ignorance given his military-history acumen. Platner, critical of Democratic leadership, has raised $4m in a tight race.

articles.title: Speaker Mike Johnson says he won’t block House vote to release Epstein files
articles.trailText: Johnson’s House has been in recess since shutdown, delaying petition to force vote on making documents public
articles.summary: House Speaker Mike Johnson said he won’t block a floor vote on a discharge petition to publicly release Jeffrey Epstein investigation files once it secures 218 signatures, but the chamber remains in recess due to the government shutdown. All House Democrats and three Republicans have signed, and Arizona Democrat Adelita Grijalva’s upcoming swearing-in will supply the final signature. Johnson refuses to reconvene the House until funding is approved, while oversight committees have independently released thousands of pages. It still needs Senate and presidential approval. President Trump opposes the release, dismissing it as a “Democrat hoax.”

articles.title: ‘We know this land’: after Typhoon Halong villages in Alaska confront costs of climate change
articles.trailText: Nearly all of Kipnuk’s 700 residents were evacuated, and officials estimate 90% of homes were destroyed
articles.summary: In mid-October, Typhoon Halong slammed Alaska’s Yukon-Kuskokwim delta with 107 mph winds and 6 ft flood surges, inundating 15 Yup’ik villages. Kipnuk saw 90% of its 700 homes and half its boardwalks obliterated; nearly all residents were air-evacuated, one body recovered and others missing. The storm exposed thawing permafrost, chronic erosion and ‘usteq’ collapses, submerged ancestral hunting trails and graves, and laid bare funding shortfalls: a rescinded $20 m EPA erosion grant, delayed FEMA aid and costly climate migration plans. Tribal leaders now demand sustained federal relief.

articles.title: Arizona boy reportedly barred from team due to error on birth certificate
articles.trailText: Laker Jackson was wrongly identified as female at birth, but high school in Mesa won’t let him play basketball with boys
articles.summary: Laker Jackson, an eighth-grader at Eastmark High in Mesa, AZ, was barred from boys' basketball tryouts after a decades-old clerical error listed him as female on his birth certificate. Despite presenting a corrected certificate and a doctor’s note, district officials insisted on costly chromosome testing to verify eligibility. Queen Creek Unified says it relies on original birth records and may consider additional documentation. Laker, who identifies as male and excels in multiple sports, has been sidelined amid nationwide, GOP-driven efforts in at least 27 states to restrict transgender athletes in school athletics.

articles.title: Mahmoud Khalil’s attorneys file appeals to prevent future Ice detentions
articles.trailText: Columbia University graduate and legal US resident says Trump administration ‘wants to make an example of me’
articles.summary: Attorneys for Mahmoud Khalil, a Columbia graduate and lawful US resident detained by ICE over his pro-Palestinian activism, have appealed to the Third Circuit to uphold a New Jersey district court’s order blocking his re-detention and deportation. Khalil was freed in June after 100 days in Louisiana; Judge Farbiarz barred removal on foreign-policy grounds. A Louisiana immigration judge later ordered his deportation for alleged green-card omissions, but his legal team says Farbiarz’s mandate prevents it. A federal judge also lifted travel limits, letting Khalil address rallies with two days’ notice amid broader challenges to targeting pro-Palestinian speech.

articles.title: Trump’s nomination of Paul Ingrassia loses Republican support following racist text messages
articles.trailText: Ingrassia, Trump’s pick to lead the office of special counsel, allegedly described himself as having ‘a Nazi streak’
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s pick for Special Counsel chief, Paul Ingrassia, faces collapsing Republican support after Politico revealed texts where he claimed a 'Nazi streak' and said Martin Luther King Jr. Day belong 'in the seventh circle of hell.' Senate leader John Thune and GOP senators Rick Scott, Ron Johnson and James Lankford oppose his confirmation. Ingrassia, a DHS liaison who backed making Jan. 6 a holiday, denies the messages as AI-generated satire. Republicans control the committee by just one vote, raising doubts about his prospects.

articles.title: January 6 US Capitol rioter arrested for alleged threat to kill Hakeem Jeffries
articles.trailText: Christopher Moynihan, pardoned by Trump for his role in Capitol attack, allegedly threatened House minority leader
articles.summary: Christopher Moynihan, 34, pardoned by Trump for his Jan 6 Capitol attack role, was arrested in New York on a felony count of making terroristic threats after allegedly sending texts vowing to kill House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. State police, alerted by an FBI joint terrorism taskforce, charged him following a detailed probe. Jeffries praised law enforcement response and condemned Trump’s blanket clemency, noting multiple pardoned rioters have reoffended. Moynihan, previously sentenced to 21 months, remains held on bail.

articles.title: At least 135 mutilated bodies of Palestinians had been held at notorious Israeli jail, say Gaza officials | First Thing
articles.trailText: Documents indicate they came from Sde Teiman. Plus, the last voyage of the Scandies Rose
articles.summary: Gaza health ministry says 135 mutilated Palestinian bodies returned by Israel were held at Sde Teiman, a Negev military base accused of torture and unlawful deaths. Documents in body bags confirm their origin. Photos and testimonies reveal detainees caged, blindfolded, shackled to beds and forced to wear diapers. Returned corpses bore blindfolds, bound hands and ligature marks. Nasser hospital doctors report evidence of murder, summary executions and systematic torture. The IDF says it has asked the Israel Prison Service to investigate. This unfolds amid renewed Israeli strikes and a fragile Gaza ceasefire.

articles.title: Biden’s ex-press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre: ‘Why are Democrats not fighting back?’
articles.trailText: Jean-Pierre explains in her new memoir Independent why she decided to leave the Democratic party after two decades
articles.summary: In Independent: A Look Inside a Broken White House, Outside the Party Lines, Karine Jean-Pierre, Joe Biden’s former press secretary, recounts two and a half years in the West Wing and her decision to leave the Democratic party after two decades. She criticizes party leadership’s panicked response to Biden’s debate performance, the media’s focus on his age, and weak strategic support for Kamala Harris. Highlighting systemic bias she faced as the first Black, out gay immigrant press secretary, Jean-Pierre urges Democrats to unite, reclaim their base and robustly challenge Trump’s authoritarian threat. She also exposes internal leaks by senior aides and the pressures of keeping cool under sexist and racist scrutiny.

articles.title: US pilots make emergency landing after mistaking static sound for plane invasion
articles.trailText: Flight returned to Omaha airport minutes after departing for Los Angeles, after intercom was left on by accident
articles.summary: Pilots aboard American Airlines Flight 6469 from Omaha to Los Angeles returned to Omaha Airport under the mistaken belief someone was trying to invade the cockpit, after a static hiss on the crew intercom—left accidentally on—was misheard as an intrusion. The Embraer ERJ-175, operated by SkyWest for American, diverted less than 40 minutes after departure. Footage reported by KABC shows the captain apologizing to passengers and citing confusion over the sound. Omaha Airport Authority confirmed no security incident. Reinforced cockpit doors, standard since 9/11, remained locked throughout.

articles.title: Fears of heat-rationing for millions in US as shutdown delays energy aid
articles.trailText: Most vulnerable families could be without critical energy assistance, experts warn, as electricity and gas bills surge
articles.summary: Federal shutdown and mass layoffs under the Trump administration have stalled release of $4 billion in Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program funds, risking heating rationing for millions this winter. Congress approved the money after blocking Trump’s proposed cuts, but program staff were fired in a so-called efficiency drive, leaving states unable to allocate aid until December. The National Energy Assistance Directors Association warns vulnerable families may face shut-offs and urges utilities to suspend disconnections. Meanwhile, gas and electricity bills have surged—up 15% in 10 states—and home-heating costs are forecast to rise 7.6% to $976, as 21 million households fall behind and shut-offs may hit 4 million in 2025.

articles.title: Infectious diseases are killing deer and risking rural US economies: ‘You smell the dead everywhere’
articles.trailText: Climate crisis contributing to spread of diseases as hunting industry takes a hit from growing number of dead deer
articles.summary: In eastern Ohio and across the Midwest, thousands of whitetail deer are dying from chronic wasting disease (CWD) and epizootic hemorrhagic disease (EHD), fueled by warmer temperatures and drought that concentrate animals at limited water holes and extend the biting midge season. Reported deer deaths in Ohio jumped from 2,093 in 2024 to 8,759 this year, wiping out local hunting-based revenues—one Airbnb lost $15,000 in canceled bookings—and threatening rural economies that rely on the $23 billion national deer-hunting industry. State agencies ban baiting, advise testing venison, and warn of waterway contamination risks. While populations can recover, funding for monitoring remains scarce.

articles.title: Santos’s release from prison felt like Trump ‘stuck me in the gut with a knife’, alleged fraud victim says
articles.trailText: Richard Osthoff says commutation was not the first time Trump did something disrespectful to a military veteran
articles.summary: Retired Navy veteran Richard Osthoff condemned President Trump’s commutation of George Santos’s 7¼-year fraud sentence, calling it a “knife in the gut” and accusing Trump of a long history of disrespect toward veterans. Osthoff alleges Santos pocketed $3,000 raised for his dying service dog, Sapphire—claims never criminally charged. Santos, expelled from Congress in 2023 after admitting wire fraud and identity theft, served only three months before Trump intervened, wiping out roughly $375,000 in restitution. His release prompted bipartisan outrage. Osthoff derided Trump as a “walking middle finger,” lamenting shame in his military service under such leadership.

articles.title: CIA playing ‘most important part’ in US strikes in the Caribbean, sources say
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Sources say the agency is providing real-time intelligence collected by satellites and signal intercepts
articles.summary: According to multiple sources, the CIA is supplying real-time satellite and signal-intercept intelligence that guides lethal US military air and drone strikes on small, high-speed Caribbean boats suspected of smuggling Venezuelan narcotics under the Trump administration. By spearheading target selection, the agency ensures key evidence remains classified rather than court-admissible. Legal experts argue the strikes violate international law against summary execution at sea. White House officials defend them as necessary against “narcoterrorist” threats. Unlike DEA or Coast Guard evidence, CIA intel is not designed for public disclosure or courtroom use.

articles.title: ‘Rogue president’: growing number of US judges push back against Trump
articles.trailText: Pushback has come from judges appointed by Republicans and Democrats – and has slowed some extreme policies
articles.summary: US district and appeals judges—appointed by Republicans and Democrats—have sharply rebuked President Trump’s emergency claims on crime and immigration, blocking deployments of the National Guard in Portland and Chicago and striking down deportation policies targeting activists. Cases by Judge Karin Immergut in Oregon, Judge April Perry in Chicago and Judge William Young in Boston found the administration’s factual assertions “untethered to the facts,” “simply unreliable” or unconstitutional. A Just Security tally shows over 40 distrust rulings and 58 arbitrary and capricious findings by mid-October. Legal experts warn of a rogue presidency abusing statutes, though a conservative Supreme Court may reverse rulings.

articles.title: US appeals court could reconsider ruling in Trump’s favor on Portland troop deployment
articles.trailText: Judge requests ‘vote on whether case should be reheard’ after panel lifted block on Trump’s planned deployment
articles.summary: A Ninth Circuit three-judge panel (2-1) lifted a district court block on Trump’s plan to federalize 200 Oregon National Guard troops for deployment in Portland, finding he has authority to protect federal property. A judge has called for an en banc rehearing: briefs from Oregon and Portland due by Wednesday; all 29 active judges will vote, and 11 will rehear. Gov. Tina Kotek and AG Dan Rayfield urge the full court to overturn, backing Judge Susan Graber’s dissent, which slammed the majority as lacking “legal or factual justification” and warned it erodes state sovereignty and protesters’ rights.

articles.title: University of Arizona becomes seventh US college to reject Trump’s ‘compact’
articles.trailText: Administration has pushed nine universities to sign a deal that seeks to make changes in line with conservative ideas
articles.summary: The University of Arizona became the seventh institution to reject the Trump administration’s 10-point “Compact for Academic Excellence in Higher Education,” which promises funding priority in exchange for reforms to admissions (race/ethnicity), hiring, gender definitions, tuition freeze, capping international undergrads at 15% and guarantees for conservative voices. President Suresh Garimella affirmed academic freedom, merit-based research funding, institutional independence and compliance with anti-discrimination laws. Six peers (Brown, Dartmouth, MIT, Penn, USC, UVA) have also declined; Vanderbilt and UT-Austin are still deliberating.

articles.title: White House’s East Wing partially demolished as work begins on Trump’s $250m ballroom
articles.trailText: Ex-congressman calls major renovation ‘utter desecration’ as demolition in East Wing reportedly under way
articles.summary: Construction crews have begun demolishing part of the White House’s East Wing to prepare for former president Donald Trump’s privately funded $250 million, 90,000 sq ft ballroom, seating up to 650–1,000 guests and featuring bulletproof glass. Trump claims no taxpayer cost and aims to complete it by January 2029. Photos from the Washington Post and the New York Post confirm visible demolition. Critics, including ex‐Rep. Joe Walsh calling it an “utter desecration,” Democratic Rep. Mark Takano proposing anti‐shutdown funding limits, and lawyer Qasim Rashid decrying the vanity spend, have voiced strong opposition.

articles.title: Joe Biden completes round of radiation therapy for prostate cancer
articles.trailText: Daughter Ashley calls father, 82, ‘so damn brave’ after treatment at UPenn clinic for aggressive cancer form
articles.summary: After his May diagnosis with an aggressive, high-risk prostate cancer that had metastasized to bone, 82-year-old Joe Biden has completed a round of radiation therapy at UPenn’s Radiation Oncology clinic. An Instagram story from daughter Ashley Biden captured him ringing the treatment bell—a symbol marking the end of a phase—and praised his courage. He previously underwent Mohs surgery in September to remove skin cancer lesions. Biden is scheduled to receive a lifetime achievement award at Boston’s Edward M. Kennedy Institute.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president can send national guard to Portland, for now
articles.trailText: Ruling marks an important legal victory for Trump – key US politics stories from Monday at a glance
articles.summary: US appeals court 2-1 ruling allows President Trump to federalize National Guard in Portland to protect federal property; Oregon AG Dan Rayfield and Gov. Tina Kotek vow full Ninth Circuit appeal. Former FBI Director James Comey moves to dismiss charges citing selective prosecution. White House East Wing demolition marks start of $250 million ballroom build. Federal shutdown enters day 20 amid GOP infighting. Trump reposts AI video of sludge-dumping plane. He signs a rare-earth minerals deal with Australia’s PM amid China trade tensions; other highlights include George Santos’ prison complaint.

articles.title: Senate vote fails again as shutdown becomes one of the longest in US history
articles.trailText: Eleventh vote fails on 50-43 tally as Congress remains deadlocked on legislation after weekend No Kings protests
articles.summary: Senate blocked a funding resolution for the 11th time (50-43) as Democrats refuse to back a continuing resolution lacking Affordable Care Act subsidy extensions. House Speaker Mike Johnson keeps the chamber in recess to pressure the Senate into adopting the GOP’s no-policy-additions bill, blaming Senate leader Chuck Schumer and nationwide No Kings protests. Hardliner Marjorie Taylor Greene publicly criticized Johnson’s strategy, signaling GOP fractures. Since Oct. 1, the shutdown—now the longest full US government shutdown—has led to furloughs of 1,400 NNSA nuclear staff. White House adviser Kevin Hassett expects a breakthrough this week.

articles.title: Trump nominee reportedly boasted of ‘Nazi streak’ in group chats
articles.trailText: Special counsel nominee Paul Ingrassia also said holidays commemorating Black people should be ‘eviscerated’
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s special counsel nominee Paul Ingrassia reportedly messaged GOP colleagues in early 2024 that he ‘has a Nazi streak,’ and urged ending the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday, along with Black History Month and Juneteenth, using racial slurs. Politico uncovered the private chat ahead of his confirmation hearing Thursday. Ingrassia, 30, defended the texts as satirical, but critics point to his inexperience, ties to white supremacist Nick Fuentes and a separate sexual harassment allegation. His nomination, set to protect federal whistleblowers, has drawn sharp bipartisan opposition.

articles.title: Three cases of severe mpox reported in California, health officials say
articles.trailText: Unrelated cases mark first time clade I of disease formerly known as monkeypox has spread within US, officials say
articles.summary: California health officials report three unrelated, locally acquired cases of clade I mpox in Long Beach and Los Angeles County—the first documented person-to-person spread of the more severe strain within the US. None of the patients traveled abroad; all were hospitalized with flu-like symptoms and a characteristic rash and are now recovering. Clade I, linked to high mortality in central and east Africa, demands close monitoring. Officials stress the Jynneos two-dose vaccine offers protection and reduces severity, especially for immunocompromised individuals, while the overall public health risk remains low.

articles.title: Comey asks judge to dismiss criminal charges claiming selective prosecution
articles.trailText: Ex-FBI director claims he is victim of selective prosecution and charges were filed by unlawfully appointed attorney
articles.summary: Former FBI director James Comey has asked a federal judge to dismiss charges of false statement and obstruction tied to his 2020 congressional testimony, arguing he’s been selectively prosecuted due to President Trump’s animus and that the case was brought by unlawfully appointed US attorney Lindsey Halligan. In a Monday filing, Comey’s lawyers cite Trump’s Truth Social post as “smoking gun,” note career prosecutors declined to indict, and allege the indictment mischaracterizes a Cruz question—focusing on Daniel Richman rather than McCabe—and violates appointment statutes by exceeding Halligan’s 120-day interim term.

articles.title: Ex-New York prison guard found guilty of murder in beating death of prisoner
articles.trailText: David Kingsley’s conviction comes after handcuffed Robert Brooks was fatally beaten at Marcy correctional facility
articles.summary: On Monday, ex-guard David Kingsley was convicted of second-degree murder and first-degree manslaughter for the December 9 fatal beating of handcuffed inmate Robert Brooks at Marcy correctional facility, all captured on body-worn cameras the guards unsuccessfully tried to deactivate. Co-defendants Matthew Galliher and Nicholas Kieffer were acquitted. Ten officers have been charged; six pleaded guilty and one faces trial in January. Brooks’s family hailed the verdict, condemned a “rotten” prison culture, and urged Gov. Hochul to enact reforms including fixed cameras in common areas.

articles.title: Trump reposts AI-generated video of plane dumping sludge on No Kings protesters
articles.trailText: President has previously posted deepfake videos and AI-generated images like this one, which JD Vance called ‘funny’
articles.summary: President Trump reposted an AI-generated 19-second clip of himself crowned “King Trump” piloting a fighter jet labeled “King Trump” dumping brown sludge on No Kings protesters—scenes of crowds in Times Square—set to an unauthorized snippet of Kenny Loggins’s “Danger Zone.” Loggins demanded its removal. This follows Trump’s earlier deepfakes lampooning Senate leader Chuck Schumer and House leader Hakeem Jeffries, which VP JD Vance called “funny.” The video highlights the GOP’s growing reliance on AI content amid nationwide No Kings protests against Trump’s second term.

articles.title: Trump claims ‘unquestioned power’ in vow to send troops to San Francisco
articles.trailText: President claims on Fox News ‘they want us in San Francisco’ despite opposition from city officials
articles.summary: President Donald Trump vowed on Fox News to deploy troops to San Francisco under the Insurrection Act, claiming “unquestioned power” and asserting local support, pointing to endorsements from tech figures like Elon Musk, David Sacks and Marc Benioff (who later retracted). This follows his contested deployments to Los Angeles and Washington DC, both facing legal injunctions. San Francisco officials, citing declining crime and constitutional limits, reject the plan. Mayor Daniel Lurie and State Senator Scott Wiener insist city residents oppose a federal military presence and affirm current law enforcement coordination is effective.

articles.title: US supreme court to consider whether drug users can legally own guns
articles.trailText: Trump administration argues that federal law prohibiting drug users from having firearms is a justifiable restriction
articles.summary: The Supreme Court will review whether federal law barring habitual illegal drug users from gun ownership violates the Second Amendment. The case stems from Ali Danial Hemani’s challenge to a felony conviction for possessing a firearm after admitting regular marijuana use during an unrelated Texas probe into alleged Iranian regime ties. The Trump administration, defending the statute that also convicted Hunter Biden, argues disarming drug users aligns with founding-era restrictions on habitual drunkards. Lower courts, citing the 2022 Bruen decision, struck down similar prosecutions. The court’s conservative majority must resolve circuit splits on this constitutional question.

articles.title: Alaska communities devastated by severe storm could take years to recover
articles.trailText: Typhoon from 11 October weekend destroyed 90% of structures and displaced 1,500 people in south-west Alaska
articles.summary: Alaska communities battered by Typhoon Halong’s remnants on 11–12 October face a multi-year recovery, warns Sen. Lisa Murkowski after visiting Kipnuk, where 90% of structures were destroyed and floods displaced 1,500 residents. At least one person is confirmed dead, two missing. Gov. Mike Dunleavy estimates up to 18 months before many can return and has requested a major disaster declaration from President Trump to unlock federal housing, utilities and heating-fuel aid. The Alaska National Guard airlifted 633 survivors. Murkowski, Sen. Dan Sullivan and Rep. Nick Begich urged Trump to approve assistance. In May the EPA canceled a $20m coastal-defense grant for Kipnuk, underscoring resilience funding gaps.

articles.title: Seventh person dies after mass shooting in Mississippi town, officials say
articles.trailText: Sixteen people were reportedly shot on 10 October after high school football game in downtown Leland
articles.summary: Officials announced that Ebanee Williams, 25, died on October 17 at University of Mississippi Medical Center, marking the seventh fatality from a mass shooting in downtown Leland, Mississippi, on October 10 following a high school homecoming game. Sixteen were wounded in the incident, one of at least 14 mass killings and over 400 mass shootings nationwide this year. Authorities have arrested nine suspects, some charged with capital murder, and believe a dispute sparked the violence. The FBI is assisting local law enforcement and urges witnesses to come forward as investigations continue.

articles.title: FBI investigates after hunting stand was found near where Trump exits Air Force One
articles.trailText: Image of hunting stand circulated by the Secret Service showed it was in a tree, near president’s Mar-a-Lago estate
articles.summary: Federal agents found a camouflaged hunting stand in a tree within sight of the Air Force One landing zone at West Palm Beach airport near Mar-a-Lago during Secret Service sweeps ahead of President Trump’s visit. No suspect was present. The FBI has taken the lead, deploying evidence collection and cell-phone forensics. Trump’s boarding protocol was tightened following the discovery. The incident follows other security threats—including Ryan Routh’s failed golf-course assassination attempt and multiple political violence cases since Trump’s second term began.

articles.title: Scramble to shore up ceasefire as Israel hits Gaza with deadly strikes | First Thing
articles.trailText: IDF says attack followed killing of two soldiers, but both sides say they are committed to ceasefire. Plus, No Kings protesters on their hopes for resistance movement against Trump
articles.summary: After Hamas killed two Israeli soldiers, Israel launched multiple airstrikes in Gaza, killing at least 28 Palestinians and cutting off all aid until further notice, marking the gravest threat to the fragile ceasefire signed in Sharm el-Sheikh. Egyptian mediators have initiated round-the-clock talks to prevent collapse, and both Hamas and the Israeli military have publicly reaffirmed their commitment to the truce. Senior US envoys, potentially including the vice-president, are set to arrive in Israel to pressure PM Netanyahu to uphold the agreement.

articles.title: ‘Contract that never was’ adds twist to scientist’s fight over Everglades project
articles.trailText: A legal saga stemming from a water quality project saw Tom Van Lent briefly jailed in a case brought by allies of DeSantis
articles.summary: Environmental scientist Tom Van Lent, jailed for 10 days and hit with $177,000 in legal costs over alleged trade-secret violations in a DeSantis-backed Everglades restoration, now claims the employment contract at the heart of the case never existed. His attorney, Michael Rayboun, accuses the Everglades Foundation—closely tied to Gov. Ron DeSantis—of perjury and fraud, seeking to reopen the settled 2022 lawsuit. The dispute stems from a scaled-down plan for a reservoir and marsh system to curb red tides and toxic algal blooms, which Van Lent and other scientists say fails federal standards and suppresses critical speech.

articles.title: The right wants Charlie Kirk memorials across the US – but is it just an attempt to capitalize on his killing?
