articles.trailText: Suspect Joshua Cole allegedly used a Facebook account to threaten revenge for murder of Charlie Kirk
articles.summary: On Sept. 18, FBI agents in Dallas arrested Abilene resident Joshua Cole for Facebook threats to “lock and load” and target “fairies” at the Sept. 20 Abilene Pride parade in retaliation for rightwing activist Charlie Kirk’s Sept. 10 killing. Using the “Jay Dubya” account, he posted violent anti-LGBTQ+ comments. After quitting his job, Cole was stopped by police, waived his rights, and admitted to the threats. He faces up to five years under federal law. Abilene Pride Alliance reaffirmed its security measures; the Trump administration has not commented.

articles.title: Donald Trump says he is deploying troops to Portland, Oregon
articles.trailText: Apparently misled by hyperbolic reporting from conservative outlets on a single small protest, president described peaceful city as ‘war ravaged’
articles.summary: President Trump announced on social media he is deploying federal troops to Portland, Oregon, claiming “war ravaged” streets and ICE facilities “under siege” by Antifa. Local leaders – Governor Tina Kotek, Mayor Keith Wilson and Congressional Democrats – say Portland is peaceful, with only a small protest outside an ICE office, and reject any request for troops. Videos cited by Trump were outdated or misleading, they say. Senators Jeff Merkley and Ron Wyden, Representatives Suzanne Bonamici and Maxine Dexter denounced the move as authoritarian, unnecessary and based on false reporting. No timeline or troop numbers have been provided.

articles.title: Police identify suspect in 1991 murders of four girls at Texas yogurt shop
articles.trailText: Officials name Robert Eugene Brashers in brutal deaths of Amy Ayers, Eliza Thomas and Jennifer and Sarah Harbison
articles.summary: After more than 34 years, Austin police have identified Robert Eugene Brashers—who died by suicide in 1999—as the DNA-linked suspect in the brutal 1991 slayings of Amy Ayers (13), Eliza Thomas (17) and sisters Jennifer (17) and Sarah Harbison (15) inside an I Can’t Believe It’s Yogurt shop. The girls were bound, gagged, shot execution-style, sexually assaulted and the store set ablaze. Renewed attention from an HBO docuseries prompted advanced testing that exonerated two men whose convictions were overturned in 2009. Brashers, with a history of violent crimes across multiple states, remains the focus of an ongoing investigation.

articles.title: US military brass brace for firings as Pentagon chief orders top-level meeting
articles.trailText: Pete Hegseth summons hundreds of generals and admirals to Virginia to meet and receive address on ‘warrior ethos’
articles.summary: Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth abruptly summoned hundreds of generals and admirals to Quantico for a top-level meeting on “warrior ethos” amid expectations of firings or demotions. The unprecedented gathering, ordered with little notice, will feature Hegseth’s ‘rally the troops’ address on fitness standards, defense-industrial base and deterrence. Sources say it signals a show of force under Trump’s second presidency, part of broader cuts to general officers, prompting unease among senior leaders and comparisons to historical purges.

articles.title: Belva Davis, a journalist who ‘opened doors for a generation’, dies aged 92
articles.trailText: Friends and colleagues remember the first Black woman hired as a TV reporter on the west coast for her ‘courage, integrity, grace and humanity’
articles.summary: Belva Davis, who died aged 92, was a trailblazing journalist and the first Black woman TV reporter on the US west coast. Born in Monroe, Louisiana, during Jim Crow, she moved to California, began in print and then anchored KPIX, KRON and KQED’s flagship news programs. Over five decades she covered Harvey Milk’s assassination, the AIDS crisis and major elections, earned eight regional Emmys and lifetime achievement honors, and mentored generations with courage, integrity and grace.

articles.title: Northwestern students blocked from enrollment after refusing controversial antisemitism training
articles.trailText: Students say mandatory training video is biased in favor of Israel and could inflame campus tensions over Gaza
articles.summary: At Northwestern University, at least 300 students have been blocked from registering after refusing a mandatory antisemitism training they say is biased toward Israel, inaccurate and risks inflaming campus tensions over Gaza. The hold—required by federal anti-discrimination rules and Trump’s 2020 executive order—threatens jobs, visas, stipends and health insurance. Produced by Jewish United Fund, the module equates critics of Israel with David Duke, labels the West Bank “Judea and Samaria” and includes anti-Arab content. Students argue it silences dissent and entrenches bias. Similar trainings are spreading amid federal funding threats, yet Northwestern still lost $790m in research support.

articles.title: Outrage mounts as Republicans in Congress move to protect pesticide makers from lawsuits
articles.trailText: Bayer, maker of Roundup weedkiller, founded group pushing to block cancer claim suits against pesticide makers
articles.summary: After inheriting 100,000+ Roundup cancer lawsuits, Bayer-backed Modern Ag Alliance has helped pass liability shields in Georgia and North Dakota and now targets federal measures in an appropriations rider and the upcoming farm bill to block pesticide litigation and prevent EPA label updates if not aligned with existing human health assessments. Consumer advocates—including the bipartisan Maha movement—alongside Democrats like Rep. Chellie Pingree and trial attorneys decry these “sneaky” provisions as unconstitutional, warning they strip consumers of legal recourse and obstruct new health risk warnings. Bayer argues federal certainty is needed to protect research and investments and disputes that the language precludes lawsuits, while also threatening to halt glyphosate sales if litigation persists.

articles.title: ‘Find it in your heart to seek the truth’: Epstein survivor pushes for lawmakers to release files
articles.trailText: Jess Michaels says authorities are ‘completely ignoring’ hers and dozens of other victims’ statements about Epstein’s trafficking
articles.summary: Jess Michaels, a former professional dancer raped by Jeffrey Epstein in 1990, has joined dozens of survivors demanding that Congress and the Department of Justice release decades-old investigative files. Despite President Trump’s campaign promise and the FBI’s claim to be “releasing as much as legally allowed,” DOJ officials insist no client list exists and refuse further disclosure. Survivors and GOP Rep. Thomas Massie point to documents identifying at least 20 men to whom Epstein allegedly trafficked victims, contradicting FBI counsel Kash Patel’s assertion of no credible evidence. Michaels decries systemic neglect, bipartisan frustration, and urges lawmakers to ‘find it in your heart to seek the truth.’

articles.title: Kamala Harris’s new book details her steep challenges without acknowledging her failures
articles.trailText: In 107 Days, Harris leaves little room for nuance – nor is she afflicted with a surplus of self-awareness
articles.summary: In her campaign memoir 107 Days, Kamala Harris contends that Joe Biden’s age-related decline and minimal lead doomed her second White House bid with just 107 days to campaign. She critiques her own timidity and indecision, laments selecting Minnesota governor Tim Walz—whose lackluster debate performance she recounts in detail—and admits passing on Pete Buttigieg. Harris celebrates breaking the Senate tie on the Inflation Reduction Act yet glosses over muddled stances on immigration, inflation and social safety nets, identity-politics jargon and a cultural disconnect with working-class voters.

articles.title: ‘A hot mess’: Florida open-carry gun ruling leads to chaos and confusion
articles.trailText: Florida’s attorney general recently said ‘open carry is the law of the state’. State officials and advocates aren’t so sure
articles.summary: Florida AG James Uthmeier hailed a 1st District appeals court ruling overturning the 1987 ban on open carry, prompting sheriffs to stop enforcing open‐carry prohibitions. Yet dozens of statutes still bar firearms in schools, hospitals, courthouses, polling places, bars and private property, leaving law enforcement, legislators and advocates in disarray. Democrats decry a "hot mess" that GOP lawmakers face in January to clarify policy. Gun safety groups warn of escalated risks; gun rights groups advise caution amid legal ambiguities.

articles.title: ‘Hell on earth’: immigrants held in new California detention facility beg for help
articles.trailText: Six people at a remote Ice facility in California City describe medical problems and filthy conditions, which operator CoreCivic denies
articles.summary: In California City’s new 2,560-bed ICE detention center, six migrants fighting deportation describe “hell on earth” conditions: filthy cells, malfunctioning toilets, limited hygiene and food rations, delayed or discarded medications triggering medical emergencies, threats of solitary confinement and force, and minimal outdoor time in harsh desert environs. Operated by CoreCivic without local permits, the facility opened in August 2025, boosting ICE capacity by 36% to over 500 detainees. CoreCivic asserts health and maintenance issues have been addressed; advocates and city officials allege unlawful operation, spurring protests and hunger strikes.

articles.title: Democrats race to embrace swearing and angry comebacks – but will it work?
articles.trailText: Democrats are abandoning their careful messaging in favor of gut-level rhetoric that’s unapologetically more profane as the party faces an authenticity problem
articles.summary: Facing decade-low approval and an authenticity crisis, Democrats from presidential hopefuls to state chairs are shedding polite talking points for raw, profane rhetoric and trolling tactics. Figures like Rep. Robert Garcia, Gov. Gavin Newsom and grassroots leader Lorena Gonzalez embrace swearing, viral memes and live-streamed hot takes on TikTok, Twitch and even Fox News to sound like “normal people” and counter Trump’s outrage machine. Guided by polling memos on what to say (and what to avoid), younger “fighter” Democrats wager that authentic anger and humor will energize disillusioned voters—though critics warn that emotion without action risks fueling frustration rather than change.

articles.title: New York man charged with parents’ murders after TV confession
articles.trailText: Lorenz Kraus, 53, tells WRGB in Albany he killed elderly parents as act of mercy and buried bodies in back yard
articles.summary: Lorenz Kraus, 53, confessed on WRGB in Albany that eight years after his parents vanished he suffocated and buried his father, 92-year-old Franz, and his mother, 83-year-old Theresia, in their backyard as an act of mercy. He described choking his father with his hands and using a rope on his mother before concealing their bodies. Charged with two counts of murder and illicitly concealing a corpse, Kraus pleaded not guilty and is held without bail. A 1994 Siena valedictorian with an MBA, he urged legal reform on mercy killings.

articles.title: Trump fires US attorney who told border agents to follow law on immigration raids
articles.trailText: New York Times reports Michele Beckwith’s firing came after she reminded Border Patrol to comply with courts
articles.summary: Donald Trump abruptly dismissed acting US attorney Michele Beckwith in Sacramento on July 15 after she instructed Border Patrol to honor an April federal court order barring indiscriminate detentions without reasonable suspicion. Beckwith, appointed in January, told El Centro Border Patrol chief Gregory Bovino via call and follow-up email to comply with the constitution and court rulings. Hours later her devices were disabled and she received a termination letter. Two days later agents raided a Home Depot. Beckwith has appealed. Her firing follows similar removals of federal prosecutors clashing with Trump’s agenda.

articles.title: Trump says he expects charges for other adversaries after Comey indictment
articles.trailText: President says ‘I think there’ll be others’ as justice department condemned for enacting retribution campaign
articles.summary: President Trump predicted further criminal charges against his “corrupt radical left” adversaries after DOJ indicted ex-FBI director James Comey for allegedly authorizing leaks. The two-count false-statement indictment, filed by Trump-appointed prosecutor Lindsey Halligan in Alexandria, narrowly secured grand jury approval despite earlier US attorney Erik Siebert deeming the evidence insufficient. Critics decry the move as politically motivated retribution by Trump’s Justice Department. Trump has also targeted New York AG Letitia James, Sen. Adam Schiff, former CIA chief John Brennan and ex-NSA adviser John Bolton, urging AG Pam Bondi to pursue charges against others who challenged him.

articles.title: Detainees shot in deadly attack on Ice facility in Dallas identified – reports
articles.trailText: Two men were injured and one was killed by an alleged lone shooter at an immigration detention center in Texas
articles.summary: Three ICE detainees—Mexican national Miguel Angel García-Hernandez, Venezuelan Jose Andres Bordones-Molina and Salvadoran Norlan Guzman-Fuentes—were shot at a Dallas detention center in a “targeted” attack by 29-year-old Joshua Jahn, who later died by suicide. Guzman-Fuentes was killed; García-Hernandez remains in critical condition after multiple operations, prompting a family fundraiser; Bordones-Molina was also injured. Both García-Hernandez, a house painter and father of four, and Bordones-Molina were undocumented; Guzman-Fuentes had past arrests. Jahn’s notes outlined the attack; Trump blames left-wing extremists despite no evidence.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president says he hopes ‘there will be others’ after Comey indictment
articles.trailText: ‘It’s not about revenge,’ Trump claims as lawmakers raise alarm over ‘blatant abuse’ of justice department – key US politics stories from Friday 26 September
articles.summary: Friday’s US politics roundup: President Trump denies Comey indictment is revenge, calls it justice and hopes for further prosecutions as Democrats warn of DOJ abuse. Other developments: ICE officer suspended after court assault video; immigrants without criminal records now the largest ICE detainee group; US blocks UN declaration on noncommunicable diseases; Arizona GOP lawmaker calls to execute a Democratic congresswoman; Abu Dhabi royal fund to take 15% of TikTok US; Trump jokes to Rolex about tariffs; plus updates on Gaza speech, Wounded Knee medals, frozen foreign aid, teen opioid treatment and Ryder Cup security.

articles.title: Trump jokingly asked Rolex executives if tariffs prompted US Open invite, CEO says
articles.trailText: Rolex CEO stressed US president’s remarks were made ‘in jest’ in letter to Elizabeth Warren, who had raised concerns
articles.summary: At the US Open final Swiss watchmaker Rolex invited President Trump to its VIP box, prompting Trump to quip—only half in jest—whether his 39% tariff on Swiss exports won him the invite. CEO Jean-Frédéric Dufour stressed in a letter to Sen. Elizabeth Warren that the invitation reflected sportsmanship, not tariff talks, and no trade discussions occurred. Warren decried the invite as potential corruption, while the White House dismissed her as peddling conspiracy theories. Trump received a golf sweater and gilet as thanks.

articles.title: Ice detains superintendent of Iowa’s largest school district
articles.trailText: Fellow educators express shock at detention of ‘beacon of light’ Ian Roberts as DHS claims he had ‘no work authorization’
articles.summary: The superintendent of Iowa’s largest school district, Ian Roberts, was detained by ICE on Sept 26 over a final removal order and lack of work authorization. Born in Guyana and raised in Brooklyn, the 54-year-old former Guyana Olympian—first person of color to lead Des Moines Public Schools—allegedly fled ICE officers and is held in Pottawattamie County. He has a prior weapons infraction from 2020. Board members and teacher unions, shocked by his arrest, contest DHS claims, have hired a third-party background check, and appointed an interim superintendent.

articles.title: Elon Musk and Peter Thiel mentioned in Epstein documents released by Democrats
articles.trailText: Prince Andrew and Steve Bannon also referenced in six-page batch of documents made public with redactions
articles.summary: Democrats released six redacted pages from DOJ files on Jeffrey Epstein’s investigations showing scheduled meetings: a breakfast with Steve Bannon (Feb 2019), a lunch with Peter Thiel (Nov 2017), and a potential Elon Musk trip to Epstein’s island (Dec 2014). An earlier manifest names Prince Andrew; a financial disclosure suggests payments to “Andrew” for services. The releases reignited social media attacks between Elon Musk, Trump allies and oversight committee members over selective document publicizing. Democrats are pushing House legislation, now likely to get the 218 signatures needed, to compel full release of Epstein files despite Senate and White House resistance.

articles.title: Hegseth says Wounded Knee massacre soldiers will keep Medals of Honor
articles.trailText: Historical records say the US army killed about 250 Lakota Sioux people in the 1890 massacre in South Dakota
articles.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced that 20 US soldiers who participated in the 1890 Wounded Knee massacre of about 250 Lakota Sioux will retain their Medals of Honor, rejecting calls for revocation. Hegseth—citing a review panel’s conclusion—called the awards justified, halting efforts by Democrats and Native activists who view the massacre of unarmed men, women and children as a genocidal atrocity. Critics accuse the Trump administration of sanitizing history amid wider actions reversing Confederate base renaming and rewriting museum narratives.

articles.title: LA car wash owner sues for $50m after being slammed and detained in Ice raid
articles.trailText: Rafie Ollah Shouhed, 79, a US citizen, was held for 12 hours after sustaining broken ribs and a traumatic brain injury
articles.summary: Rafie Ollah Shouhed, a 79-year-old US citizen and owner of a Van Nuys car wash, has filed a $50 million suit against DHS, CBP, ICE and Border Patrol after agents allegedly body-slammed him, causing broken ribs and a traumatic brain injury, and detained him for 12 hours despite proof of citizenship. His attorney alleges constitutional and civil rights violations amid a surge of aggressive Trump administration raids in southern California, noting video of masked agents using excessive force. Shouhed was never charged and released the same day; ICE said he impeded an operation and was arrested but released without charges.

articles.title: Former priest who served under two Louisiana governors arrested for allegedly raping disabled child
articles.trailText: Mark Francis Ford is accused of sexual crimes allegedly starting in 2004 against a then 10-year-old boy
articles.summary: Mark Francis Ford, 64, a former Vincentian priest and disability affairs official under Governors Blanco and Jindal, was arrested in Portage, Indiana, on charges of first-degree rape, kidnapping, sexual battery and indecent behavior with a juvenile. Federal agents say he began abusing a then-10-year-old boy with a spinal cord condition and autism in 2004 through a ministry for disabled children and continued until 2022–23. The accuser, now 31 and under permanent tutorship, reported the abuse in November, prompting a New Orleans warrant and extradition proceedings. Ford faces mandatory life for first-degree rape and lengthy sentences on other counts. His arrest is the fifth involving New Orleans clergy since the archdiocese’s 2020 bankruptcy, which proposes a $230 million settlement with abuse survivors.

articles.title: ‘Dangerous abuse of power’: lawmakers sound alarm over Comey indictment
articles.trailText: Democrats and legal experts say indictment is latest sign Trump is turning justice system into weapon to silence critics
articles.summary: Former FBI director James Comey was indicted in the Eastern District of Virginia on one count of making a false statement to Congress and one count of obstruction for his 2017 testimony on the Russia investigation. The charges came after US attorney Erik Siebert was removed and replaced by Trump loyalist Lindsey Halligan. Senate Democrats including Mark Warner, Adam Schiff and Hakeem Jeffries denounced the move as a “dangerous abuse of power” and “malicious prosecution” aimed at silencing critics. The ACLU and pro-democracy groups warned the indictment undermines the rule of law and every citizen’s right to criticize leaders. Republicans Ted Cruz and Chuck Grassley argued holding Comey accountable is legitimate, while Trump assailed him as a “dirty cop” on social media and pledged more retribution against opponents.

articles.title: Trump v Comey: a timeline of the president and ex-FBI director’s feud
articles.trailText: A grand jury indicted James Comey for obstructing a congressional proceeding in a culmination of a years-long conflict
articles.summary: 2015: Comey downplayed politics in Clinton email probe; July 2016 found Clinton 'extremely careless' but no charges. Trump seized on it, calling the FBI 'rigged'. After 2016 election Comey led the Russia investigation; in May 2017 Trump fired him. Comey testified to the Senate about Trump’s loyalty demands and published a memoir accusing Trump of unethical leadership. After Trump’s 2025 return the Secret Service surveilled Comey over a deleted anti-Trump post. In September 2025 a grand jury indicted Comey for false statements and obstructing Congress; prosecutors and Senate Democrats condemned it as weaponizing justice. Comey pleaded innocence; Trump celebrated on Truth Social.

articles.title: Rare orange lobster found in New York supermarket returned to sea
articles.trailText: ‘One-in-30m’ find spared from menu and released into Long Island Sound after being spotted in upstate grocery store
articles.summary: A rare bright-orange lobster—estimated at a 1-in-30 million rarity—was spotted live in a Tops supermarket tank in upstate New York by shopper Kyle Brancato, who improvised care by borrowing tank water from local restaurant Palmer’s and buying a 20-gallon sea-water tank from Petco, cooling it to the proper temperature. Nicknamed Jean-Clawed Van Damme, the lobster was handed to Humane Long Island and the New York Aquarium and released into Long Island Sound on Sept. 24, a day before National Lobster Day. Amid thousands boiled during peak harvest, this one was spared, echoing a 2021 Ontario rescue.

articles.title: Man who killed four people in New York City building containing NFL headquarters had CTE
articles.trailText: Medical examiner says autopsy of Shane Tamura, who played football in high school, showed evidence of brain disease
articles.summary: Medical examiner autopsy confirms that Shane Tamura, the 27-year-old mass shooter who killed four people — a security guard, a Blackstone executive, a police officer and a Rudin Management employee — and himself at a Manhattan office housing NFL headquarters on July 28, had low-stage chronic traumatic encephalopathy. Tamura, a former high school football player, left a note blaming the NFL for concealing head trauma risks. Postmortem brain tissue showed “unambiguous diagnostic evidence” of CTE, a degenerative disease linked to repeated concussions. While CTE is tied to impulsivity and rage, experts say its role in violent behavior remains under study.

articles.title: Ice officer ‘relieved of duties’ after video shows him manhandling woman at New York immigration court
articles.trailText: Monica Moreta-Galarza was pleading with officer to release her detained husband when he pushed her to the ground
articles.summary: A federal ICE officer was suspended after video showed him pushing Ecuadorian mother Monica Moreta-Galarza—who with her young daughter pleaded for her detained husband—across a hallway and to the floor at Manhattan’s 26 Federal Plaza immigration court. DHS called the conduct “unacceptable” pending investigation. Democratic Rep. Dan Goldman and City Comptroller Brad Lander have urged felony charges for excessive force and civil-rights violations. Observers reported prior incidents by the agent amid rising ICE arrests in courthouse corridors, deaths in custody and detentions of non-criminal migrants.

articles.title: Assata Shakur, an icon of Black liberation who was exiled to Cuba, dies aged 78
articles.trailText: Shakur spent decades exiled after she was convicted of killing a state trooper in 1977 and escaped from prison
articles.summary: Assata Shakur, former Black Liberation Army member and enduring symbol of Black liberation, died aged 78 on Sept 25 in Havana of age-related causes. Born JoAnne Byron in 1947 Queens and raised under segregation, she was politicized during the civil rights era, joined the Black Panthers then the BLA, adopting her African name meaning ‘one who struggles.’ Convicted in 1977 for the 1973 Mecklenburg shootout that killed Trooper Werner Foerster, she escaped New Jersey’s Clinton Correctional in 1979, won asylum in Cuba, and was placed on the FBI’s terrorist list in 2013. Her memoir and life inspired racial justice movements.

articles.title: Ice detainees hold hunger strike at Louisiana state penitentiary
articles.trailText: Nineteen in immigration processing unit striking for access to medical and mental health care, among other demands
articles.summary: Nineteen ICE detainees at the Louisiana State Penitentiary’s Angola-based processing unit (Camp J), dubbed the “Louisiana Lockup” or “Camp 57,” are on a fifth-day hunger strike, demanding access to medical and mental health care—particularly prescription medications—and basic necessities like hygiene products, toilet paper and clean drinking water. They also seek visitation by ICE officers, law library access and religious programming, all mandated under federal standards. Advocates warn chronic illness patients have been denied life-saving meds and cite Camp J’s history of abuse. DHS counters that detainees continue receiving three meals daily and sufficient water. Louisiana now detains the nation’s second-largest immigrant population.

articles.title: Republican Arizona lawmaker makes post calling for execution of Democratic congresswoman
articles.trailText: John Gillette on X called for ‘people like’ Pramila Jayapal to be ‘hanged’ in response to her video on anti-Trump protests
articles.summary: Arizona state rep. John Gillette (R) on X called for Pramila Jayapal to be tried, convicted and hanged, misrepresenting her call for nonviolent protests against the Trump administration in a March video. Gillette, a retired Army reserve sergeant major, has defended Jan. 6 rioters as “political prisoners” and labeled Muslims “terrorists.” His execution post escalates a pattern of far-right rhetoric targeting Democratic officials and reflects a broader GOP push to criminalize dissent. Jayapal’s footage, taken from her “The Resistance Lab,” explicitly urges peaceful protest and warns of political violence. Gillette has not responded to requests for comment.

articles.title: People in California: tell us what you think about Proposition 50
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from Californians about how they view the redistricting proposal
articles.summary: On November 4, Californians will vote on Proposition 50, which temporarily shifts authority for redrawing congressional districts from an independent citizens’ commission to the state legislature until 2031, before reverting. Advocates argue it counters Texas’s GOP-driven plan by potentially adding up to five Democratic US House seats. Californians are asked to share their views on Prop 50, report any campaign outreach, and reflect on its impact on their communities.

articles.title: Ex-FBI director James Comey indicted on two charges as Trump pushes to prosecute political enemies
articles.trailText: Comey, one of Trump’s frequent targets, indicted on counts of making false statements and obstruction of a congressional proceeding
articles.summary: Former FBI director James Comey was indicted in Alexandria, Virginia, on one count of making a false statement to Congress and one count of obstruction of a congressional proceeding, centered on his September 2020 testimony in the Russia probe. The grand jury action, ordered after President Trump pressed Attorney General Pam Bondi and replaced the US attorney in Virginia with ex-Trump aide Lindsey Halligan, is seen as part of Trump’s campaign to prosecute political adversaries. Comey insists on his innocence, welcomes trial and faces up to five years in prison. Democrats and ex-DOJ officials decry the move as a politicized attack on the rule of law.

articles.title: Several demonstrators arrested outside Netanyahu’s hotel ahead of UN speech
articles.trailText: About two dozen protested after midnight, carrying flags and signs and calling out ‘baby killer’ and ‘free Palestine’
articles.summary: About two dozen demonstrators staged a late-night protest outside Benjamin Netanyahu’s Manhattan hotel ahead of his UN general assembly address, chanting “baby killer,” “free Palestine” and waving Palestinian flags. Police herded the non-violent crowd onto the sidewalk and arrested several participants. The action—aimed at disrupting Netanyahu’s sleep—coincides with his expected defiant stance on Israel’s Gaza offensive, which has killed at least 65,000 Palestinians and injured 167,000 since October 2023. In recent days, the UK, Canada, Australia, France and Portugal formally recognized a Palestinian state, a move Netanyahu denounced as a “reward for terrorism.”

articles.title: ‘It’s all performative’: why are shooters leaving messages on shell casings?
articles.trailText: The use of markings on ammunition is a new trend of shooters trying to ensure their messages are disseminated publicly, experts say
articles.summary: Experts say shooters are increasingly inscribing or writing messages on shell casings and magazines to broadcast ideological or personal statements, as seen in recent high-profile U.S. attacks—from Minneapolis to ICE to the Buffalo grocery shooter—echoing historic wartime inscriptions. Tracing back to the 2019 Christchurch massacre, these performative acts draw on extremist online subcultures, embedding cryptic memes and slogans (“Hey fascist! Catch!”, “Anti-ICE”). Researchers warn law enforcement and policymakers must decode this trend’s internet roots, amid distress for victims’ families confronted with bizarre, insider messaging.

articles.title: Ice detainees death toll reaches 16 amid concerns over ‘horrendous’ conditions
articles.trailText: Rising toll worries activists as mass detention in US increases after Trump returned to White House in January
articles.summary: At least 16 detainees have died in ICE custody since January under Trump’s second term, including former Dreamer Ismael Ayala-Uribe in Adelanto and a Honduran national in New York; a detainee in Dallas was also shot by a gunman targeting an ICE facility. Detainee numbers jumped from 39,238 to over 60,000. Activists and Senators Warnock and Ossoff decry ‘horrendous’ conditions amid a death rate nearing 1.9/month, while ICE defends 24-hour medical care.

articles.title: Teen opioid addictions often untreated as youth overdose deaths rapidly rise in US – study
articles.trailText: Drug overdoses are now a leading causes of death among US teens as fentanyl possibly drives surge, researchers warn
articles.summary: Study in Health Affairs finds under 1 in 3 US teens with opioid use disorder receive treatment and under 10% access medication-assisted therapy (MAT). Teen overdose deaths hit 557 in 2023—threefold 2018 levels—while adult deaths rose 65%. Researchers link this surge to counterfeit fentanyl pills circulating via social media, legal hurdles and stigma, and a pre-2024 requirement to try non-medical interventions first. Experts urge adolescent-specific protocols, family/community support teams and contingency management incentives to expand MAT access and curb fatal teen overdoses.

articles.title: Immigrants with no criminal record now largest group in Ice detention
articles.trailText: Government data shows 16,523 people with no record, versus 15,725 with a record and 13,767 with pending charges
articles.summary: Government data show 16,523 immigrants with no criminal history are now in ICE detention—surpassing the 15,725 with convictions and 13,767 with pending charges—out of about 59,762 detained. Under Trump’s second term, ICE has expanded arrests, enlisting CBP, FBI, DEA and local law enforcement to meet directives to detain thousands daily. Critics note many arrests are collateral, sweeping up long-term residents and visa holders, exemplified by raids at a Georgia Hyundai site. DHS insists 70% of arrestees have criminal records, but advocates warn civil infractions are being treated as crimes amid record detention levels.

articles.title: James Comey indicted on two charges as Trump pushes to prosecute political enemies | First Thing
articles.trailText: Ex-FBI director indicted on counts of making false statements and obstruction of a congressional proceeding. Plus, human origins may reach back far deeper in time than previously thought
articles.summary: Former FBI director James Comey was indicted on false-statement and obstruction charges over his September 2020 Russia-investigation testimony, marking a new move in President Trump’s retribution campaign. DOJ’s Pam Bondi affirmed that “no one is above the law.” Meanwhile, Trump issued a memorandum targeting a so-called leftwing “domestic terror network,” rejected Israeli annexation of the West Bank, brokered a $14 bn deal for Abu Dhabi’s MGX to take 15% of TikTok US, and announced steep new tariffs on drugs, trucks and cabinets.

articles.title: Gaza and Ice protesters exposed to teargas in the US report disrupted menstrual cycles
articles.trailText: Toxic crowd-control chemicals used in Michigan and LA have caused long-lasting health effects, activists say
articles.summary: Activists in Michigan, Los Angeles and Newark who were exposed to teargas or 'Deep Freeze'—a mix of CS gas and pepper spray—during Gaza and ICE protests in 2024-25 report persistent menstrual disruptions, including severe cramps, heavy or irregular bleeding, hormone imbalances, fatigue and weight gain. More than a dozen people across three demonstrations cited these issues, mirroring a 2021 Portland study finding reproductive and respiratory harm among 900 women. Experts warn of long-term risks—respiratory disease, cancer, organ damage—while regulations lag, prompting calls for peer-reviewed research and policy reform.

articles.title: How James Comey moved to the top of Trump’s enemies list
articles.trailText: The former FBI director was fired by Trump in 2017, and has been a longtime target for the president
articles.summary: After firing FBI director James Comey in 2017 for refusing a loyalty oath and publicly confirming a Russian election interference probe, President Trump has long sought to criminally pursue him. This week, a Trump-appointed U.S. attorney in Virginia indicted Comey, raising questions about political motivation. Ironically, Comey’s 2016 decisions—clearing Hillary Clinton of email server charges then reopening the probe days before the election—bolstered Trump’s campaign, while Robert Mueller’s 2019 report, triggered by Comey’s firing, found no coordination between Trump’s team and Russia despite clear evidence Moscow sought to help him.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Comey says he knew there would be cost ‘to standing up’ to president, as he is indicted
articles.trailText: Former FBI director James Comey has said he is innocent, adding ‘let’s have a trial and keep the faith’. Key US politics stories from 25 September 2025 at a glance
articles.summary: Former FBI Director James Comey was indicted on false statements to Congress and obstruction charges in Trump’s campaign against adversaries. Comey declared his innocence, urging a trial and expressing faith in the DOJ. AG Pam Bondi affirmed that no one is above the law after Trump tweeted "JUSTICE IN AMERICA!" swinging retribution. Other highlights: Texas ICE shooting suspect’s anti-ICE motive; DOJ probing Soros’s Open Society Foundations; Trump’s domestic terror memo and hefty new tariffs on drugs, trucks and cabinets; TikTok divestiture order; Disney investors’ Jimmy Kimmel probe; removal of Trump-Epstein statue; and ongoing federal watchdog disputes.

articles.title: Trump signs memo targeting ‘domestic terrorism’ amid fears of crackdown on the left
articles.trailText: US president criticizes ‘anarchists and agitators’ as he unveils memo expected to meet fierce legal pushback
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s presidential memorandum directs the FBI, DOJ and Treasury to “investigate, disrupt and dismantle” what he labels a radical leftwing domestic terror network. He hinted at targeting funders such as George Soros and Reid Hoffman, drawing swift legal and civil liberties pushback from the ACLU. Legal experts argue the memo adds no new crimes but risks politically selective enforcement. Announced amid fallout from Charlie Kirk’s murder and a Dallas ICE attack, the plan—hailed by Stephen Miller—lumps disparate violent incidents under antifa, raising fears of broad suppression of dissent.

articles.title: White House tells agencies to prepare for firings if government shuts down
articles.trailText: Democrats accuse Trump of intimidation tactics after memo outlines much more aggressive step than previous shutdowns
articles.summary: An August OMB memo directs agencies to draft force‐reduction plans in case of a government shutdown next week, targeting programs lacking funding or misaligned with Trump’s priorities—a more aggressive alternative to normal furloughs. House Democrats Jeffries and Senate Democrats Schumer denounce the plan as intimidation, promising legal challenges. Trump blames Democrats’ ACA subsidy demands and illegal‐immigrant provisions for the impasse. The memo orders agencies to maintain minimal staff for core functions, citing GOP legislation’s funding for key priorities. Meanwhile, GSA recalls hundreds laid off under Musk’s efficiency drive to return in October. The showdown intensifies as Congress races to pass a short‐term continuing resolution.

articles.title: ‘Heartbroken’: staff laid off as California TV station abruptly closes newsroom
articles.trailText: KION-TV announces partnership with San Francisco CBS affiliate as workers condemn ‘disservice to the community’
articles.summary: KION-TV, a 50-year broadcaster on California’s central coast, abruptly closed its Salinas/Santa Cruz/Monterey newsroom this week, laying off over a dozen staff. The News-Press & Gazette owner will cease full local newscasts, instead partnering with San Francisco’s KPIX CBS to share state headlines while promising limited local segments. Telemundo 23 also shuts, leaving a majority-Latino region without Spanish-language news. Staff decry a “disservice to the community”, citing national decline of local journalism. Employees get pay through contract year or relocation offers; many left heartbroken. According to Muck Rack, US local news staffs have dropped 75% since 2002, with one in three counties lacking any full-time local journalist.

articles.title: Dallas shooting suspect left ‘anti-Ice’ notes but wasn’t part of any specific group, officials say
articles.trailText: Texas authorities say the shooting at an Ice detention center came after a ‘high degree of planning’
articles.summary: In Dallas on September 24 a 29-year-old Fairview, Texas man, Joshua Jahn, opened fire from a rooftop at an ICE detention center after a “high degree of planning,” killing one detainee and critically wounding two. Officials recovered anti-ICE notes outlining a game plan targeting agents (not detainees), evidence he used ICE tracking apps and downloaded DHS facility lists. Authorities say he acted alone, wasn’t tied to any group, and died by suicide on scene. FBI and the US attorney stressed no organizational links, and President Trump and local leaders condemned anti-ICE rhetoric as fueling extremist violence.

articles.title: US authorities remove Trump-Epstein statue from National Mall
articles.trailText: Interior department says National Park Service removed statue of pair holding hands because of incorrect permit
articles.summary: Anonymous art collective The Secret Handshake erected an impromptu statue of Donald Trump and Jeffrey Epstein holding hands on Washington’s National Mall for ‘Friendship Month’, then the National Park Service removed it hours later for permit noncompliance, Interior spokesperson Elizabeth Peace said. The work satirizes Trump’s 2002 praise of Epstein—he called him a ‘terrific guy’—and reflects anger over undisclosed ‘Epstein files’. Artist ‘Patrick’ defended the piece, contrasting it with the administration’s eagerness to restore contested Confederate monuments. The White House blamed Democrats, media and critics for inaction on Epstein’s victims while touting document releases.

articles.title: Trump’s European ‘hell’ is made in America | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Responding to the president’s UN speech, Michael Newman looks at US foreign policy in the Middle East and Africa, while Terry Hansen says Trump is shirking climate responsibilities
articles.summary: Two letters respond to President Trump’s UN speech. Michael Newman argues Trump’s claim that Europe is going “to hell” due to immigration ignores America’s role in fomenting conflicts in Iraq, Syria, Lebanon, Libya, Sudan, Eritrea and Afghanistan, whose war-driven displacement waves now challenge Europe despite US instigation. Terry Hansen rebuts Trump’s dismissal of climate agreements as “globalist,” warning unchecked emissions fuel fires, floods and food shortages; he urges industrialised nations to leverage their fossil-fuel-built prosperity to lead a clean energy transition, framing cooperation as responsibility rather than self-punishment.

articles.title: Merch sellers cash in on Kirk’s killing with flood of social media ads
articles.trailText: Foreign brands not linked to Kirk’s Turning Point USA sell patriotic gear with unclear promises to donate profits
articles.summary: Within hours of Charlie Kirk’s assassination, Guangzhou Shiwei Network Technology, based in Panyu, China, launched at least nine foreign-run brands (e.g. See Jesus In You, Liberty Faith Gear, USA Freedom T) to flood Facebook and Instagram with Kirk-memorial shirt ads, falsely pledging profits to Turning Point USA. The Guardian identified seven more brands from companies like Harbin Huanjia Trading and Jinhua Hongrun E-Commerce. Using fake US addresses and dozens of social accounts aimed at patriotic, faith and veteran audiences, this astroturfing echoes past election exploits. Meta removed some ads but many still run.

articles.title: Oklahoma superintendent who put Trump Bibles in classrooms resigns
articles.trailText: Ryan Walters, who has led Oklahoma public schools since 2022, is quitting to run a conservative education non-profit
articles.summary: Ryan Walters, Oklahoma superintendent since 2022, is resigning to lead the conservative Teacher Freedom Alliance (TFA). Famous for placing Trump-endorsed Bibles in classrooms, forcing 2020 election conspiracy theory lessons and pushing Christian nationalist policies—including a proposed Catholic charter school and Turning Point USA chapters—he vows to “destroy” teachers’ unions, certify teachers with an “America First” credential and build a national movement against the “woke liberal union mob.”

articles.title: ‘Hidden costs’ of climate emergency are worsening California’s affordability crisis – report
articles.trailText: University of California, Berkeley, study found that those who experience severe effects will see upto a $1m in costs
articles.summary: A UC Berkeley Center for Law, Energy & Environment report, commissioned by Next 10, finds California households face hidden climate costs—rising utility bills, lost wages and health expenses—that worsen the state’s affordability crisis. An average Californian born in 2024 will incur up to $500,000 in extra lifetime costs (up to $1 million under severe exposures). Wildfires have generated $4.6 billion in GDP losses in January alone, $300 million in lost wages, and $60 billion in income losses since 2017. Smoke-related health impacts cost $84 per person daily and triggered $7.8 billion in Bay Area health expenses in 2018. Outdoor workers may lose $55.4 billion in future earnings by 2050 due to extreme heat and poor air quality. The report warns that failing to act on climate change will inflate immediate and long-term living costs and calls for policy focus on climate solutions to address California’s affordability crisis.

articles.title: US is violating human rights laws by backing fossil fuels, say young activists in new petition
articles.trailText: Petition says that US government’s protection of fossil fuel interests has put people in harm’s way
articles.summary: Fifteen youth climate activists, including plaintiffs from Juliana v. US, filed a petition to the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights, arguing US support for fossil fuels violates international law and their rights under the American Declaration on the Rights and Duties of Man. They detail harms—repeated hurricane displacement, school closure—assert breaches of rights to life, health, culture and access to justice. They demand precautionary measures, a public hearing, and a declaration of wrongful acts to pressure the US to curb emissions despite non-binding IACHR recommendations. Their action follows advisory opinions on states’ duty to set ambitious greenhouse gas targets.

articles.title: Fema’s acting chief reportedly could not be reached during deadly Texas floods
articles.trailText: Disaster relief agency reportedly didn’t answer two-thirds of calls after criticism for slow response during devastation
articles.summary: After July’s deadly Texas floods, which washed away a youth Christian summer camp and killed at least 138 people, FEMA’s acting administrator David Richardson was mostly unreachable, delaying search-and-rescue and causing nearly two-thirds of disaster hotline calls to go unanswered, according to a Washington Post report based on eight current and former officials. A new DHS policy forcing Secretary Kristi Noem to sign off on any expenditure over $100,000 further slowed relief. FEMA declined to comment on the Post’s findings. Rep. Frank Pallone has called for Richardson’s resignation; he defended his response at a July congressional hearing.

articles.title: House Democrats to send letter to Trump on Friday urging US to recognize Palestinian statehood
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Letter, led by Ro Khanna, has 46 signatories and calls for ‘long overdue need to recognize Palestinian self-determination’
articles.summary: Forty-six House Democrats led by Ro Khanna will send Trump and Secretary Rubio a letter on Friday, coinciding with the UN General Assembly, urging formal U.S. recognition of Palestinian statehood. Citing over 60,000 Gaza deaths, widespread famine and displacement, they call for Macron’s framework requiring Hamas’s disarmament and collaboration with the Palestinian Authority and Arab allies to guarantee Israel’s security. Endorsed by J Street, the move tests Democratic leaders amid Trump’s public opposition and Netanyahu’s refusal. A parallel Senate resolution by Jeff Merkley is seen as unlikely to clear the GOP-controlled chamber.

articles.title: ‘I was reborn’: Cincinnati imam reflects on 10 weeks in Ice custody after release
articles.trailText: Ayman Soliman recalls isolation, abuse and fear of deportation and the community that fought for his release
articles.summary: Ayman Soliman, a 51-year-old Egyptian imam and former Cincinnati hospital chaplain, spent 10 weeks in Butler County jail under ICE custody after a July check-in. Isolated in freezing cells, denied prayer space and legal contact, he feared deportation to torture in Egypt. His release and visa restoration, secured by local advocacy and pro-bono lawyers, marks a setback for the Trump administration’s aggressive deportation policies. Soliman aims to resume his chaplaincy and obtain a green card, highlighting broader due-process concerns for detained immigrants nationwide.

articles.title: Petition by man against Ice custody may provide new path to release for others
articles.trailText: Rodney Taylor, who is a double amputee, filed a habeas corpus after being held in a Georgia center for eight months
articles.summary: Rodney Taylor, a Liberia-born double amputee with pending green card status, has filed a federal habeas corpus petition after eight months in ICE’s Stewart detention center. He argues his prolonged, bond-less confinement—despite severe medical needs and prosthetic injuries—lacks lawful basis and challenges a September Board of Immigration Appeals ruling that all but eliminated bond for long-term detainees. His case, seen as a test for nationwide habeas claims, is spurring immigration lawyers to train in federal court filings to free similarly detained migrants.

articles.title: Trump’s CDC cuts could threaten chronic illness and national security, experts warn
articles.trailText: Public health leaders worry proposed 53% CDC slash would weaken disease prevention and pose a national security risk
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s 2025 budget slashes CDC funding by 53%, cutting 61 programs and 16% of staff after federal clawbacks exceeding $12 billion. Experts warn eliminating cancer, diabetes, HIV/AIDS, immunization, substance use and emergency preparedness initiatives will fuel chronic illness, widen health inequities in rural and marginalized communities and weaken outbreak response ahead of events like the FIFA World Cup. With 80% of CDC funds flowing to state and local agencies—already hobbled by delays and 20,000 staff departures—public health leaders say these cuts threaten national health security and could depress US life expectancy further.

articles.title: ‘Neglected’: preservation group moves to protect US Latino heritage sites as funding threats loom
articles.trailText: The Latinos in Heritage Conservation group warns various sites are in danger of being lost forever due to lack of funds
articles.summary: Latinos in Heritage Conservation has released “Endangered Latinx Landmarks,” naming 13 vulnerable US sites—from colonial‐era churches, street markets and historic neighborhoods to Chicano murals in D.C. and L.A.’s Silver Platter LGBTQ+ bar—at risk of disrepair, gentrification and the Trump administration’s proposed cut of the Historic Preservation Fund from $169m to $11m. Published for Hispanic Heritage Month, the list, vetted by preservationists, historians and community leaders, is a call by executive director Sehila Mota Casper to urgently invest in these neglected community anchors and safeguard Latinx cultural memory.

articles.title: One dead and two injured in shooting at Texas Ice facility | First Thing
articles.trailText: Authorities say all three people shot were detainees at Dallas facility. Plus, WHO rejects Trump’s claims of link between Tylenol and autism
articles.summary: One detainee was killed and two wounded in a pre-dawn shooting at a Dallas ICE facility; the 29-year-old suspect died of a self-inflicted wound after firing from an adjacent building, and anti-ICE slogans were found on shell casings. The WHO dismissed claims linking prenatal acetaminophen use to autism, sparking GOP resistance to health policy. Gaza’s southern hospitals are overwhelmed by displaced patients with blast injuries and hunger. Briefs: Trump calls Sadiq Khan ‘terrible’; Texas driver thwarts motel hostage plot; drone strike injures 20 in Eilat; exonerated Californian wins $25M; fossil fuels threaten 1.6B health; Scottish teen targets single-use plastics.

articles.title: Deadly Ice shooting comes as violence spikes amid Trump immigration crackdown
articles.trailText: Trump officials seek to tie attacks to ‘radical left’ as agencies accused of violent tactics against migrants and protesters
articles.summary: On September 25, a sniper opened fire from a roof onto a Dallas ICE detention center, killing one detainee, wounding two others and then himself. Authorities found “anti-ICE” scrawled on a spent bullet; FBI and Trump allies blamed “radical left terrorists,” while Democrats decried political violence. ICE reports a 700% surge in assaults on its agents this year – including ambushes in Texas and shootings at CBP sites – amid the agency’s intensified immigration crackdown. Critics counter that ICE and CBP have used excessive force against migrants and protesters, underscoring a broader, bipartisan extremism threat.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Obama says the US caught between two visions of the future as he criticises the president
articles.trailText: Obama said Donald Trump’s claims linking paracetamol to autism in infants is ‘violence against the truth’. Key US politics stories from 24 September 2025
articles.summary: Former president Obama warns the US is torn between progressive democracy and conservative populism, criticises complacent liberals and labels Trump’s paracetamol–autism link ‘violence against the truth’. In Dallas, an ICE office shooting kills one detainee and the gunman; Trump blames ‘radical left Democrats’. At the UN, Trump alleges ‘triple sabotage’ over escalator and teleprompter failures. Energy secretary plans to return green-project funds. Rolex faces tariff backlash for hosting Trump. Leaders push climate targets as WHO refutes acetaminophen claims. Oklahoma to install Turning Point USA chapters in schools; VA doctors warn of policy threats to veterans.

articles.title: California officials investigate death of Mexican man in Ice custody
articles.trailText: Ismael Ayala-Uribe, who suffered from hypertension, was transferred from a center to a hospital to treat an abscess
articles.summary: Authorities are investigating the death of 39-year-old Mexican national Ismael Ayala-Uribe, who died early Monday after being transferred from the Adelanto ICE Processing Center to a regional hospital for surgery on a buttock abscess. ICE officials say he suffered hypertension and tachycardia; hospital staff found him unresponsive and pronounced him dead. His family alleges repeated medical neglect since his Aug. 22 arrival, citing ignored fevers and coughing. A long-time California resident and former DACA recipient with two DUI convictions, he was detained in a workplace raid. Mexico’s consulate is offering legal assistance and monitoring the inquiry; this marks the second ICE custody death this week.

articles.title: Escalatorgate: Trump alleges ‘triple sabotage’ after technical mishaps at UN
articles.trailText: Trump claims teleprompter and audio issues, and a stopped escalator that UN says may be due to US delegation staffer
articles.summary: At the UN General Assembly, President Trump alleged “triple sabotage” after an escalator carrying him and Melania stopped – UN says a US delegation videographer triggered a safety stop – his teleprompter went dark and audio cut out. He improvised parts of his speech, lamenting Melania “couldn’t hear a word,” though video showed delegates reacting. Demanding an “escalatorgate” investigation and citing a London Times jab at funding cuts, he used his address to lambaste the UN and warn Europe on migration. White House press sec. Karoline Leavitt vowed accountability if staffers aimed to humiliate them.

articles.title: Obama says Trump linking paracetamol to autism is ‘violence against the truth’
articles.trailText: Former president says successor’s claims about drug branded Tylenol in US ‘undermines public health that can do harm to women’
articles.summary: At a London event, former US president Barack Obama condemned Donald Trump’s warning that prenatal paracetamol (Tylenol) causes autism in infants as “violence against the truth,” cautioning that continuously disproved claims undermine public health and risk deterring pain relief for pregnant women. Trump’s advice was rebuked by UK Health Secretary Wes Streeting. Obama framed the dispute as part of a broader battle between democratic progressive change and a conservative-populist rollback, warning complacent progressives to stay vigilant. He spoke to historian David Olusoga at the O2 Arena during his European tour ahead of Dublin’s Freedom of the City.

articles.title: Texas Ice facility shooting: what we know so far about deadly attack
articles.trailText: One detainee was killed and two were critically wounded in shooting the White House says is ‘politically motivated’
articles.summary: At a Dallas ICE field office, a 29-year-old gunman, identified as Joshua Jahn, opened fire at detainees in a sallyport van on Sept. 24, killing one and critically wounding two before shooting himself. DHS corrected initial casualty figures, confirming one deceased. No law enforcement officers were injured. Shell casings found bore “anti-ICE” slogans, prompting an FBI investigation into politically motivated violence. Officials withheld victim identities. Texas Gov. Abbott deemed it an “assassination,” while DHS Sec. Noem and political figures including Trump and VP Vance blamed left-wing rhetoric, though motives remain unconfirmed.

articles.title: Texas Ice facility shooting: Republicans blame ‘radical left’ as Democrats focus on victims and gun control
articles.trailText: Democrats say Trump allies are using incident for ‘political points’ against the left despite the victims being detainees
articles.summary: A sniper attack at a Dallas ICE facility killed one detainee, left two critically wounded, and spared all federal staff; the gunman died by suicide. FBI investigators found anti-ICE messages but have not confirmed a motive. Republicans (Trump, Abbott, Cruz) denounced “radical left” rhetoric against law enforcement, while Democrats and gun-control advocates condemned the politicization, spotlighted detainees’ families, urged gun reform and decried anti-immigrant sentiment. DHS and ICE withheld victim identities pending further inquiry.

articles.title: Murdoch’s TikTok? Trump offers allies another lever of media control
articles.trailText: Under the known terms of the deal with China, TikTok would get a new board, including Murdochs and Ellisons
articles.summary: Trump announced a tentative US–China deal enabling TikTok to keep operating under new US ownership and oversight: Oracle would license its recommendation algorithm and handle security, joined by Rupert and Lachlan Murdoch, Larry and David Ellison, and others on a seven-member US board. The arrangement grants his billionaire allies unprecedented sway over Fox, Paramount, Warner assets and TikTok’s youth audience, skirting FCC anti-monopoly rules amid a Trump-packed commission and reshaping American media power.

articles.title: Texas Ice facility shooting: one dead and two injured, and ‘anti-Ice’ shell casings found
articles.trailText: Authorities said all three people shot were detainees at Dallas facility and that alleged shooter killed self
articles.summary: At a Dallas ICE field office, detainee Joshua Jahn, 29, opened fire from an adjacent building around 6:40 am, killing one fellow detainee and critically wounding two others before fatally shooting himself. Investigators recovered shell casings engraved with “ANTI ICE,” triggering an FBI probe into a politically motivated attack. All victims were ICE detainees, including a Mexican national whose consulate is providing support. Dallas PD, DHS and FBI are investigating motive. Political leaders from Trump and Abbott to Cruz condemned the violence and are monitoring developments.

articles.title: Trump energy secretary to return billions set aside for green projects
articles.trailText: Chris Wright attacks Joe Biden’s ‘Green New Scam agenda’ and says climate accords have not lowered emissions
articles.summary: US energy secretary Chris Wright will return $13bn in Biden-era green funding to the Treasury, labeling the ‘Green New Scam’ wasteful and insisting international climate accords haven’t curbed emissions. He defended a contested DOE report, argued climate action drives up energy costs and imperils grid reliability, and claimed 30 years of accords from Kyoto to Paris failed to alter emissions trajectories. Wright said he’s investigating wind farms for whale impacts, has reversed renewable project permits while keeping coal online, and declines to attend COP30.

articles.title: Rightwing podcasters run rampant with Charlie Kirk conspiracies: ‘It’s craven opportunism’
articles.trailText: After the Turning Point USA CEO’s killing, Candace Owens and other far-right stars are trying to persuade listeners of unfounded theories about Israel and federal involvement
articles.summary: After Charlie Kirk’s assassination, the rightwing podcast ecosystem has exploded with competing theories and opportunistic spin. Kirk’s own show reclaimed the top chart spot with celebrity hosts calling for retribution against the “far left.” Candace Owens, now No.2 on Spotify’s trending chart, has systematically cast doubt on the lone-shooter narrative, alleging without evidence a shadowy Israeli-linked conspiracy and threats from hedge-funder Bill Ackman. Other figures – from Joe Rogan to Tucker Carlson, Glenn Beck and JD Vance – have alternately questioned the weapon’s logistics, blamed leftists, or invoked antisemitic blood libel. Influencers like Ian Carroll and Jackson Hinkle echo anti-Zionist tropes, forcing Netanyahu and Ackman to publicly deny involvement. Experts call this “craven opportunism,” as podcasters scramble to monetize grief and distrust official accounts.

articles.title: Rolex faces questions over Trump US Open invitation amid tariffs pain
articles.trailText: Elizabeth Warren sends letter to Swiss watchmaker asking if it was trying to ‘curry favor’ with the president
articles.summary: Rolex invited President Trump to its corporate box at last month’s US Open final, mere weeks after his administration slapped a 39% tariff on Swiss exports—far above the EU’s 15% and the UK’s 10%. Senator Elizabeth Warren has challenged CEO Jean-Frederic Dufour, asking if the invitation was intended to curry favor for special-interest tariff exemptions on models like the $163,200 Oyster Perpetual Lady-Datejust, warning of potential corruption. Trump attended alongside senior officials, including Treasury Secretary Bessent, AG Bondi, Press Sec. Leavitt and Jared Kushner. A White House spokesperson derided Warren’s concerns; Rolex declined to comment.

articles.title: Trump’s UN speech: what he said about London, oil and the UK’s green policies
articles.trailText: From claims about sharia law to warnings on renewable energy, US president’s address was highly critical of Britain. But do his arguments stand up?
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s 55-minute UN address targeted London’s mayor Sadiq Khan with baseless “sharia law” claims, mischaracterised falling crime and accused the UK of overtaxing North Sea oil despite data showing 90% of future output from existing fields, and companies profited under wartime prices while an IEA-backed windfall tax applied. He slammed green policies “ruining” farmland, ignoring that solar farms occupy less land than golf courses, sheep graze beneath turbines, and onshore wind has lagged since a 2015 ban. Critics denounce his remarks as racist lies and environmental myths; Norway’s $1.8 trn oil fund offers a countermodel.

articles.title: Oklahoma official says all high schools will have Turning Point chapters after Charlie Kirk killing
articles.trailText: Conservative youth group chapters will counter ‘woke indoctrination’, says Ryan Walters
articles.summary: Oklahoma Superintendent of Public Instruction Ryan Walters announced every high school will host Turning Point USA’s high-school arm, Club America, to counter what he calls “woke indoctrination” by teachers unions. Under a charter agreement, three students and a teacher sponsor can launch a chapter, backed by TPUSA’s activism kits. He warned schools risk losing accreditation if they refuse. Requests for chapters spiked after the killing of activist Charlie Kirk. Walters, known for pushing religion, “America First” certification, election-fraud content, Trump-branded Bibles and conservative committees, presides over one of the poorest-ranked education systems in the US.

articles.title: Rodents prevail in rat race: New York City’s rat czar resigns from post
articles.trailText: Mayor Eric Adams said effort to end rodent problem would ‘continue at full steam’ despite Kathleen Corradi’s exit
articles.summary: New York City’s rat czar Kathleen Corradi, appointed by Mayor Eric Adams in 2023 with a $3.5m budget for public awareness and rat contraception, will resign effective October 10 and shift to an undisclosed city role. She had promised New Yorkers ‘a lot of me and a lot less rats’ when taking the post. Under her tenure, estimated rat population remains about 3 million but 311 rat-related calls fell 24% year-over-year in January; 79% of complaints were addressed within 14 days in FY25, up 14%. Adams praised her ‘confidence and creativity’ and vowed to press ahead ‘at full steam’ against rodents.

articles.title: Trump faces Republican backlash over Kennedy’s autism and vaccine claims
articles.trailText: Senators warn health secretary’s advice on Tylenol in pregnancy lacks scientific basis, raising alarm in GOP ranks
articles.summary: After Trump and HHS Secretary RFK Jr.’s White House press conference linking prenatal Tylenol to autism, GOP senators led by Senate health committee chair Bill Cassidy — joined by Susan Collins and Lisa Murkowski — warned the assertion lacks scientific basis, demanding HHS release supporting data and holding hearings. Cassidy noted risks to pain management for pregnant women; ex-CDC chief Susan Monarez alleges Kennedy pressured her to endorse vaccine policy changes without data. Medical organizations such as the Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine and ACOG continue to endorse acetaminophen for pregnancy pain and fever.

articles.title: Trump’s housing department rolls back work to combat residential segregation, whistleblowers allege
articles.trailText: Allegations against Hud are latest sign of administration’s plans to transform enforcement of US civil rights laws
articles.summary: Whistleblowers at HUD’s Office of Fair Housing (OFH) allege Trump appointees have effectively halted enforcement of the 1968 Fair Housing Act, thinning OFH’s 31-member staff by seven and threatening to cut it to 11, and impeding cases via gag orders. A sister office faces 77% staff cuts, shuttering a domestic-violence branch. Several racial- and Hispanic-bias suits—including against a Texas HOA and a lender—were dropped or weakened. OFH attorneys Palmer Heenan and Paul Osadebe sued HUD Secretary Scott Turner while Sen. Elizabeth Warren has asked for an inspector-general probe. Critics warn decades of anti-segregation gains are imperiled.

articles.title: VA doctors warn cuts, privatization threaten veterans’ healthcare
articles.trailText: Roughy 170 physicians and other medical workers claim Trump administration has weakened veterans’ health system. Trump officials deny their policies are hurting veterans
articles.summary: Nearly 170 current and former VA physicians, psychologists and therapists signed a whistleblower letter—the “Lincoln Declaration”—warning that aggressive staff cuts and expanded privatization under the Trump administration threaten the VA’s integrated healthcare system for 9 million veterans. They argue closures of VA facilities and diversion of resources to costlier, ill-equipped private providers will undermine care for complex conditions like PTSD, TBI and toxic-exposure cancers. VA officials deny harm, pointing to new infrastructure investments and increased private‐provider access, while critics note a $12 bn reduction in VA funding and “severe” staffing shortages documented by the inspector general.

articles.title: Trump’s change in tone is valuable to Ukraine – but more than words are needed
articles.trailText: US president’s assertion that Kyiv can regain all land lost to Russia can only be achieved through more direct help on the battlefield
articles.summary: After abandoning his earlier push for Kyiv to cede Donetsk, Trump now asserts Ukraine can retake all its territory, marking a strategic tone shift but offering only limited measures: tougher sanctions (mainly aimed at India, not China), European-funded U.S. arms shipments, and no new air-defense aid. Analysts argue that real battlefield gains require heavier Western weapon supplies, improved air defense, or unlikely direct military intervention, or a Russian collapse. Kyiv itself has acknowledged that diplomatic negotiations will be needed to recover regions occupied since 2014.

articles.title: Trump uses UN speech to attack global body as feckless and pernicious | First Thing
articles.trailText: US president calls for countries to close their borders and expel foreigners. Plus, Kimmel says silencing comedians ‘anti-American’ in return to air
articles.summary: At the UN General Assembly—his first in six years—Trump attacked the UN as feckless, corrupt and “pernicious,” urged nations to close borders and expel foreigners, and called on Europe to adopt his blood-and-soil nationalism. He vowed Ukraine could reclaim all territory lost to Russia and pressed NATO to ban Russian oil. Meanwhile, Jimmy Kimmel returned to air denouncing government efforts to silence comedians as “anti-American,” fueling a broader free-speech debate.

articles.title: Trump’s Tylenol announcement incurs furious backlash: ‘This is yet more utter rubbish’
articles.trailText: Medical professionals, pregnant women and autistic people note guidance’s disconnect from reality
articles.summary: After Trump linked prenatal Tylenol use to autism, hundreds of medical experts, pregnant women, and autistic individuals denounced the claim as unfounded, politically motivated and misogynistic. Respondents branded it a distraction from the Epstein files and part of Project 2025’s control agenda, criticized the White House’s scientific ignorance and scaremongering. Autistic advocates warned the rhetoric echoes eugenicist thinking and undermines neurodiversity, urging respect for evidence-based care and women’s autonomy.

articles.title: Stained panties, male guards and no privacy: what it’s like to have your period in prison
articles.trailText: In my 15 years of incarceration, I’ve seen women’s bodily needs constantly disregarded. One solution could grant us back some dignity
articles.summary: In this first-person account, Kelsey Dodson, incarcerated 15 years at Oklahoma’s Eddie Warrior facility, describes menstrual management as a public ordeal: women get only 15 pads, 10 tampons and seven white panties per month, face communal laundry with watered-down soap and no bleach, male guards’ indifference and frequent stained underwear. She argues for dark-colored underwear to restore dignity to the 190,000+ women menstruating behind bars.

articles.title: Trump says he believes Ukraine can regain all land lost to Russia since 2022 invasion
articles.trailText: US president claims Russia is in ‘big economic trouble’ as he calls for Nato countries to stop imports of Russian oil
articles.summary: Trump declared Ukraine capable of recovering all territory lost since Russia’s 2022 invasion, citing Russia’s economic troubles, after meeting Zelenskyy. Posting on Truth Social, he urged EU/NATO to provide financial and military support, stop Russian oil imports, and consider strong tariffs on non-compliant nations. He pledged US-supplied weapons to NATO allies and suggested shooting down Russian aircraft violating airspace. Zelenskyy hailed this as a major shift, hoping Trump can sway China. The EU is discussing accelerating an end to Russian gas imports by 2026 and targeted measures against Indian and Chinese refineries, while Hungary and Slovakia resist halting Russian energy due to infrastructure limits.

articles.title: Delivery driver foils Texas hostage situation after alerting police to alarming order details
articles.trailText: Driver called police after seeing that delivery order to motel room included zip ties, hatchet, bleach and trash bags
articles.summary: Monday morning in Sweetwater, Texas, a delivery driver flagged police after a motel-room order contained trash bags, zip ties, bleach and a hatchet. Officers confronted 42-year-old Neil Cooper, who claimed he was armed and held a hostage. The victim escaped and Cooper surrendered after negotiations by Texas DPS. He faces aggravated kidnapping and illicit drug manufacture/delivery charges; the alleged hostage was also arrested on ID and outstanding drug warrants. Initial bystanders misidentified the courier as a DoorDash driver; the company said he wasn’t on its platform. Users lauded the alert delivery person.

articles.title: The Democratic superlawyer Trump can’t silence: ‘We are in the break-glass moment of American history’
articles.trailText: Marc Elias has long defended high-profile Democrats and election law, resisting Trump’s crackdown on his opponents
articles.summary: Marc Elias, a leading Democratic election attorney who built his reputation advising Al Franken’s 2008 recount and representing Hillary Clinton, Kamala Harris and the DNC, won 64 of 65 challenges to Trump’s 2020 results and hired researchers behind the Steele dossier. Targeted by Trump executive orders and a presidential memo calling for disciplinary action, he faces verbal attacks and antisemitic threats but continues litigating via Elias Law Group and Democracy Docket. He warns of a “break-glass moment” for US democracy, urging persistent legal fights as firms capitulate under political pressure.

articles.title: Adelita Grijalva wins her late father’s House seat in Arizona special election
articles.trailText: Grijalva will be state’s first Latina in Congress, shrinking Republicans’ House majority even further
articles.summary: Adelita Grijalva, daughter of late Rep. Raúl Grijalva, won Arizona's heavily Democratic 7th district special election, becoming the first Latina from the state in Congress. She defeated Republican Daniel Butierez and shrank the GOP's slim House majority. A longtime Tucson school board member (20 years) and Pima County supervisor since 2020, Grijalva overcame a primary challenge by progressive organizer Deja Foxx. She vows to defend democracy, immigrant rights, expand Medicaid/Medicare, and pursue Medicare for All and the Green New Deal.

articles.title: Trump angered by ‘bad escalator’ at UN as White House vows to investigate malfunction
articles.trailText: Press secretary speculates the escalator stopped on purpose to humiliate president, but UN says safety function may have been ‘inadvertently triggered’
articles.summary: During his UN visit, Donald Trump faced a halted escalator and a malfunctioning teleprompter. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt announced an investigation into whether UN staff purposely stopped the escalator to humiliate the president, citing prior jokes about US funding cuts. Trump mocked both failures in his General Assembly speech, calling them ‘bad escalator’ and ‘bad teleprompter.’ UN spokesman Stéphane Dujarric explained a built-in safety mechanism was inadvertently triggered, resetting the escalator, and noted the teleprompter is operated by the White House.

articles.title: New statue on National Mall celebrates ‘long-lasting bond’ between Trump and Epstein
articles.trailText: Bronze-sprayed statue by an anonymous creator shows the two men frolicking and holding hands with a foot kicked back in joy
articles.summary: A bronze-sprayed, anonymously created statue installed on the east end of Washington’s National Mall depicts former President Donald Trump and convicted sex trafficker Jeffrey Epstein frolicking, hand-in-hand, celebrating their “long-lasting bond,” per a plaque. Granted a National Park Service permit through Sunday evening, the piece echoes previous satirical Trump installations. Its plaques reproduce lines from an alleged letter Trump wrote in Epstein’s 50th birthday book referencing shared “enigmas.” The sculpture reignites scrutiny of their past friendship—fueling divisions within the MAGA base—and prompted a White House response dismissing Epstein’s association as common knowledge.

articles.title: Win for former executives suing LA Film School as 2024 lawsuit unsealed
articles.trailText: Allegations of student loan fraud, lies to US education department and mass deception may lead to huge payout
articles.summary: 2024 whistleblower suit by former LAFS VPs Ben Chaib and Dave Phillips, unsealed Sept 2025, alleges the for-profit Los Angeles Film School committed student loan fraud and lied to the Education Department by inflating its key 70% job-placement rate—actual rate closer to 20%—through mass deception, fake hires via a music company (nearly $1M paid for two-day gigs) and linking recruiter bonuses to enrollments. DOJ declined involvement; plaintiffs seek federal aid clawbacks and a 25–30% whistleblower share. School calls suit a money grab.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president backs Ukraine to ‘get their land back’ from Russia and lambasts UN
articles.trailText: Trump shows support for Kyiv, attacks allies over immigration and denounces the UN on its 80th birthday. Key US politics stories from 23 September at a glance
articles.summary: After meeting Zelenskyy, President Trump claimed on Truth Social that Ukraine, with EU and NATO support, can “fight and win” back all territory seized by Russia since 2022, calling Russia a “paper tiger”. At the UN’s 80th anniversary, he denounced the organisation as corrupt, urged border closures and expulsion of foreigners. In other developments, global health agencies dismissed his unverified autism–painkiller link; he canceled talks with congressional Democrats over a looming shutdown; Defense Secretary Hegseth disbanded a women’s military advisory panel; US deportations to Ghana sparked rights concerns; and Fed chair Powell defended the central bank’s independence.

articles.title: Cold case found? Body unearthed is Oregon’s oldest unidentified person case
articles.trailText: Oregon state police say remains of ‘Oak Grove Jane Doe’ have been recovered after nearly 80 years
articles.summary: Oregon state police recovered remains believed to be Oak Grove Jane Doe—Oregon’s oldest unidentified murder victim after her dismembered body was dumped in the Willamette River in April 1946. Wrapped in burlap sacks, parts washed ashore over decades, the petite white woman aged 30–50 suffered blunt force head trauma. Crucial evidence went missing in the 1950s. Located under an “Unknown Woman 1946” headstone by the state medical examiner’s Human Identification Program, the remains will undergo advanced forensic testing to finally identify her.
